A.| last5=Deser| last3=Tomas| issue=11| bibcode=2008GeoRL..3511506L| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090320104125/http://www.cgd.ucar.edu/ccr/dlawren/publications/lawrence.grl.submit.2008.pdf| archivedate=2009-03-20| df=}}{{cite pressrelease|date=June 10, 2008|title=Permafrost Threatened by Rapid Retreat of Arctic Sea Ice, NCAR Study Finds|url=http://www.ucar.edu/news/releases/2008/permafrost.jsp|publisher=[[University Corporation for Atmospheric Research|UCAR]]|accessdate=2009-05-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100118170723/http://www.ucar.edu/news/releases/2008/permafrost.jsp|archivedate=January 18, 2010|df=}} Methane clathrates on the sea-floor have also been predicted to destabilise, but much more slowly. A release of methane from clathrates, however, is believed to be slow and chronic rather than catastrophic and that 21st-century effects of such a release are therefore likely to be 'significant but not catastrophic'. It is further noted that 'much methane from dissociated gas hydrate may never reach the atmosphere',{{cite journal|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/96/7/3420.full.pdf+html|title=Potential effects of gas hydrate on human welfare|first=Keith A.|last=Kvenvolden|journal=[[PNAS]]|accessdate=2009-05-23|date=March 30, 1999|volume=96|issue=7|pages=3420–3426|doi=10.1073/pnas.96.7.3420|pmid=10097052|bibcode = 1999PNAS...96.3420K|pmc=34283 }} as it can be dissolved into the ocean and be broken down biologically. Other research{{Cite journal| first1 = T. | first2 = L. | first3 = F. | first4 = P.| title = Evidence for large methane releases to the atmosphere from deep-sea gas-hydrate dissociation during the last glacial episode| last3 = Bassinot| last4 = Henry| url = http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=15197255| format = Free full text| journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America| volume = 101| issue = 25| pages = 9187–9192| last2 = Beaufort| date=Jun 2004 | issn = 0027-8424| pmid = 15197255| pmc = 438951| last1 = De Garidel-Thoron| doi = 10.1073/pnas.0402909101|bibcode = 2004PNAS..101.9187D }} demonstrates that a release to the atmosphere can occur during large releases.{{Clarify|date=May 2009}} These sources suggest that the [[clathrate gun]] effect alone will not be sufficient to cause 'catastrophic' climate change within a human lifetime. [[James E. Hansen|Hansen]] et al. 2013 suggests that the Earth could become in large parts uninhabitable and note that this may not even require burning of all fossil fuels, because of higher climate sensitivity (3–4 °C or 5.4–7.2 °F) based on a 550 ppm scenario. Burning all fossil fuels would warm land areas on average about 20 °C (36 °F) and warm the poles 30 °C (54 °F).{{cite journal | last = Hansen | first = James |date=September 2013 | title = '''Climate sensitivity, sea level and atmospheric carbon dioxide''' | journal = Royal Society Publishing | volume = 371 | doi = 10.1098/rsta.2012.0294 | url = http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/371/2001/20120294 | issue=2001 |display-authors=etal | pages=20120294| arxiv=1211.4846 | bibcode=2013RSPTA.37120294H | pmc=3785813 }} Earlier estimates were based on the assumption that fossil-fuel use would continue until reserves were exhausted, and predicted a [[runaway greenhouse effect]], a climate similar to that on [[Venus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.columbia.edu/~jeh1/2008/AGUBjerknes_20081217.pdf|format=PDF|title=Climate Threat to the Planet|last=Hansen|first=James|date=2008-12-17|accessdate=2009-10-10}} Ongoing research determines if such a [[climate state]] is possible on Earth.{{cite web |author1=Kendall Powell |author2=John Bluck |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Tropical 'runaway greenhouse' provides insight to Venus | publisher = NASA Ames Research Center | year = 2002 | url = http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2002/02_60AR.html}}{{cite journal|author1=Fricke, H. P.| last=Hoffman | title = A Neoproterozoic Snowball Earth| last4=Schrag| url=http://marine.rutgers.edu/ebme/HistoryEarthSystems/HistEarthSystems_Fall2008/Week6a/Hoffman_et_al_Science_1998.pdf | journal = [[Science (journal)|Science]]| volume = 281 | issue=5381| pages = 1342–1346 | year = 1998 | doi = 10.1126/science.281.5381.1342 | pmid=9721097|bibcode = 1998Sci...281.1342H }} Modeling work shows that such an event would indeed be a result of a self-sustaining ice-albedo effect,{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.2153-3490.1969.tb00466.x|author=M.I. Budyko|title=Effect of solar radiation variation on climate of Earth|journal=Tellus|year=1969|volume=21|issue=5|pages=611–1969|url=http://www.math.umn.edu/~mcgehee/Seminars/ClimateChange/references/Budyko1969Tellus21p611-Albedo.pdf |format=PDF|bibcode=1969TellA..21..611B}} and that such a condition could be escaped via the accumulation of CO2 from volcanic outgassing.{{cite book|last=Kirschvink|first=Joseph|editor=J. W. Schopf; C. '''Science advice''' is the process, structures and institutions through which governments and politicians consider science, technology and innovation information in policy- and decision- making. Across different national governments and international bodies, there are a variety of structures and institutions for scientific advice. They reflect distinctive cultures and traditions of decision-making, which [[Sheila Jasanoff]] has termed the ‘civic epistemology’<ref>{{cite journal |url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11016-008-9201-6#page-1 |title= Controlling Biotechnology: Science, Democracy and ‘Civic Epistemology’|date=2008-05-07 |accessdate= 2015-05-31 |doi=10.1007/s11016-008-9201-6 |volume= 17 |journal=Metascience |pages= 177–98}}</ref> through which expert claims are constructed, validated or challenged in a given society.
Science advice can also be called "science for policy," indicating the flow of information from scientific to policy domains with the intention of informing decisions. This is distinct from "policy for science," the institutions, rules and norms governing how science is funded, conducted, and communicated.
At the national level, countries have diverse models for how to connect scientists and policymakers. In some countries, the president of the [[National academy]], an elected organization of distinguished researchers in natural and social sciences, engineering, medicine, and the humanities, serves as a government science advisor, while other countries have an advisory committee or civil servants perform this role.<ref name="guardian">{{cite web | first1 =James | last1 = Wilsdon | first2 = Kristiann | last2 = Allen | first3 = Katsia | last3 = Paulavets |url= https://www.theguardian.com/science/political-science/2014/aug/27/a-rough-guide-to-science-advice |title=A rough guide to science advice | Science | work =The guardian | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> National academies are often commissioned to write reports advising government on the state of scientific knowledge to inform policy-relevant questions, such as the risk from chemicals or disease.
Other countries, such as the UK, have a wide range of sources of expert scientific advice which draw on several of these sources.<ref name= "globalscienceadvice.org">{{cite web|url= http://www.globalscienceadvice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/08/Science_Advice_to_Governments_Briefing_Paper_25-August.pdf |format=PDF |title=Science Advice to Governments: Diverse systems, common challenges |publisher= Global science advice |accessdate= 2015-05-31}}</ref>'''
At the international level, there is an increasing movement to bring together national science advisors to share best practices and form a network to deal with global challenges (e.g., pandemics, climate change). The first global Science Advice to Governments meeting was held in Auckland, New Zealand on August 27–28, 2014. This meeting brought together high-level science advisors, scientists, and practitioners to discuss the relationship between science and policy.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.globalscienceadvice.org/ |title=INGSA |publisher= Global science advice | accessdate= 2015-05-31}}</ref> A new network of European science academies was established at the European Open Science meeting in Copenhagen in June 2014,<ref name= "guardian" /> which now includes 20 countries.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.slideshare.net/SciAdvice14/1000-days-in-the-life-of-a-science-advisor-38529597 |title=1000 days in the life of a science advisor |publisher=Slideshare | accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref>
The [[International Council for Science]] (ICSU) is a major international organization with a program in science for policy.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.icsu.org/science-for-policy/ |title= Introduction: Science for Policy |publisher=ICSU |date= 2015-05-25 |accessdate= 2015-05-31}}</ref>
== Science advice structures == A briefing paper,<ref name="globalscienceadvice.org" /> described four of the most commonly used science advice structures for jurisdictions: advisory councils, advisory committees, national academies, and chief scientific advisors. These structures are most commonly employed at the national level, but may also be used in sub-national jurisdictions like Quebec, or supra-national bodies like the [[European Commission]], which has an in-house science service, the [[Joint Research Centre]].
Science advice also occurs at sub-national levels, where structures may include departmental scientific advisors (for example, the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]], and at the international level, where networks such as the [[International Council for Science]] coordinate science for policy, for example through serving as the science voice in the [[United Nations]].
For any of these structures, individual experts may be asked for advice in specific circumstances.
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Science Advice Structure<ref name= "globalscienceadvice.org" />!! Explanation<ref name= "globalscienceadvice.org" /> |- | Advisory councils || Many economies have a high-level council for science (or science and innovation) policy. Members typically include senior scientists, alongside representatives of industry, higher education and civil society. Examples include Japan’s Council for Science, Technology and Innovation (CSTI) and the US President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST). Another example is Australia, where chief scientist Ian Chubb recently announced that he plans to establish a new science council to advise government on policy. However, in most systems, the focus of such entities remains on policy advice in relation to the science system, which is distinct from science advice for public policy.
|- | Advisory committees || Most governments also rely on an array of specialized scientific and expert committees, which can address detailed technical and regulatory issues in areas such as health, environment and food safety. For example, the US and Japan have hundreds of such committees; the UK has over seventy. |-
|- | National academies || A growing number of national academies are active in science policy and/or policy for science. In economies such as Canada, China, Germany, Netherlands, South Africa, US and UK, academies are an important source of scientific advice. Furthermore, networks of national academies such as the International Council for Science, with a membership of 121 national bodies, representing 141 economies, and 31 International Scientific Unions, and the Inter-Academy Panel, the global network of science academies from 107 economies are actively involved in science for policy processes at the international level. |-
|- | Chief scientific advisors || The first chief scientific advisor was appointed by the US in 1957, followed by the UK in 1964. The first chief scientific advisor in Quebec, Canada, was appointed in 2011. |}

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Teri Garr |image = Teri Garr in The Black Stallion.jpg |imagesize = |alt = |caption = Garr {{circa}} 1978 |birth_name = Teri Ann Garr |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Lakewood, Ohio]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |occupation = {{hlist|Actress|dancer}} |years_active = 1963–2011 |spouse = {{marriage|John O'Neil
|1993|1996|end=divorced}} |partner = [[Roger Birnbaum]] (1979–1983)
David Kipper (1983–1990) |alma_mater = [[California State University, Northridge]] |children = 1 }} '''Teri Ann Garr''' (born December 11, 1944){{efn|Sources vary in regard to Garr's birth year. While December 11 is uniformly the listed date, sources have cited 1944,{{sfn|Leszcak|2014|p=52}} 1945,{{sfn|Hellmann|2006|p=1925}} 1947,{{cite web|work=[[United Press International]]|url=https://www.upi.com/Famous-birthdays-for-Dec-11-Rita-Moreno-Hailee-Steinfeld/9581512968882|title=Famous birthdays for Dec. 11: Rita Moreno, Hailee Steinfeld|author=UPI Staff|access-date=October 21, 2018}} and 1949.{{sfn|Willis|2005|p=332}}}} is a retired American actress, singer, and dancer. She frequently appeared in comedic roles throughout her career,{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=How to Be Funny|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/12/magazine/12hodgman.html|date=November 12, 2006|author=Hodgman, John|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022015427/https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/12/magazine/12hodgman.html|archive-date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} which spans four decades and includes over 140 credits in film and television. Her accolades include one [[Academy Award]] nomination, a [[BAFTA Award]] nomination, and one [[National Board of Review]] Award. Born in [[Lakewood, Ohio]], Garr was raised in [[North Hollywood, Los Angeles|North Hollywood]], California, the third child of a [[vaudeville|vaudevillian]] father and costume designer mother. In her youth, Garr trained extensively in [[ballet]]. She began her career as a teenager with small roles in television and film in the early 1960s, including appearances as a dancer in nine [[Elvis Presley]] musicals. After spending two years attending college, Garr left Los Angeles and studied acting at the [[Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute|Lee Strasberg Institute]] in New York City. Garr had a supporting role in [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s thriller ''[[The Conversation]]'' (1974) before having her film breakthrough as Inga in ''[[Young Frankenstein]]'' (1974). In 1977, she was cast in a high-profile role in [[Steven Spielberg]]'s ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]''. Garr continued to appear in various high-profile roles throughout the 1980s, including supporting parts in the comedies ''[[Mr. Mom]]'' (1983) and ''[[Tootsie]]'' (1982), for the latter of which she was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] for her role Sandra Lester. She reunited with Coppola the same year, appearing in his musical ''[[One from the Heart]]'' (1982), followed by a supporting part in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s [[black comedy]] ''[[After Hours (film)|After Hours]]'' (1985). Her quick banter led to Garr being a regular guest on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' and [[David Letterman]]'s late night talk shows in the 1980s. In the 1990s, she appeared in two films by [[Robert Altman]]: ''[[The Player (film)|The Player]]'' (1992) and ''[[Prêt-à-Porter (film)|Prêt-à-Porter]]'' (1994), followed by supporting roles in ''[[Michael (1996 film)|Michael]]'' (1996) and ''[[Ghost World (film)|Ghost World]]'' (2001). She also appeared on television as [[List of Friends characters#Phoebe Abbott|Phoebe Abbott]] in three episodes of the sitcom ''[[Friends]]'' (1997–98). In 2002, Garr announced that she had been diagnosed with [[multiple sclerosis]], whose symptoms had impacted her ability to perform beginning in the 1990s.{{Cite web|work=E! Online|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/54084/garr-better-after-brain-aneurysm|title=Garr Better After Brain Aneurysm|author=Grossberg, Josh|date=January 3, 2007|access-date=October 21, 2018}} ==Early life== Teri Ann Garr was born in [[Lakewood, Ohio]], a suburb of [[Cleveland]]. Her father, Eddie Garr (born Edward Leo Gonnoud, 1900—1956),{{sfn|Garr|2006|p=68}} was a [[vaudeville]] performer, comedian, and actor whose career peaked when he briefly took over the lead role in the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] drama ''[[Tobacco Road (play)|Tobacco Road]]''. He changed his surname before Teri's birth. Her mother, Phyllis Lind Garr (1909—1999) (born Emma Schmotzer),{{sfn|Garr|2006|p=68}} was a dancer, a [[The Rockettes|Rockette]], [[Wardrobe supervisor|wardrobe mistress]], and model.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/22/Teri-Garr.html|title=Teri Garr profile|website=Filmreference.com|accessdate=December 11, 2016}}{{cite news|first=Edward|last=Guthmann|date=January 7, 2004|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2004/01/07/DDGD343TKC1.DTL&type=printable|title=As acting jobs dwindle, Teri Garr takes up her pen|work=San Francisco Chronicle}}{{cite web|url=http://docs.newsbank.com/g/GooglePM/BG/lib00065,0EADEAD18E1E4492.html|website=Boston.com|title=Local Search|publisher=newsbank.com|accessdate=September 5, 2017}} Her father was of Irish descent and her maternal grandparents were Austrian immigrants.{{sfn|Garr|2006|p=68}} Garr has two older brothers. She spent her early life in Cleveland, and the family briefly relocated to [[New Jersey]] before settling in [[Los Angeles]], California. When Garr was 11 years old, her father died in Los Angeles of a [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]]. She recalled that his death "left us bereft, without any kind of income. And I saw my mother be this incredibly strong, creative woman who put three kids through college—one of my brothers is a surgeon. Any kind of lessons we wanted, we had to have scholarships or sweep the floors. It had to be free. And so we always had to try harder. That was instilled in me very early." During her youth, Garr expressed interest in dancing, and trained extensively in [[ballet]]. "I'd go for three, four hours a day; my feet would be bleeding," she recalled. "I'd take buses all over the city just to go to the best dancing schools. You could just stand there and be quiet and beat yourself up, push the body." Garr graduated from [[North Hollywood High School]], and attended [[California State University, Northridge]] for two years before dropping out and relocating to New York City to further pursue acting. In New York, she studied at the [[Actors Studio]]{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1988-10-30-8802110709-story.html|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|location=Chicago, Illinois|title=Is Teri Garr Serious When|author=Steinmetz, Johanna|date=October 30, 1988|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021095055/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1988-10-30-8802110709-story.html|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 21, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} and the [[Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute]].{{cite news|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20031028&slug=terigarr28|title=An MS diagnosis curbed Teri Garr's film career — but not her morale|author=Johnston, Steve|location=Seattle, Washington|date=October 28, 2003|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021235637/http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20031028&slug=terigarr28|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ==Career== ===1963–1967: Early films and stage=== Early in her career she was credited as '''Terri Garr''', '''Terry Garr''', '''Teri Hope''', or '''Terry Carr'''. Her movie debut was as an extra in ''A Swingin' Affair'' (1963). During her senior year she auditioned for the cast of the Los Angeles road company production of ''[[West Side Story]]'', where she met one of the most important people in her early career, [[David Winters (choreographer)|David Winters]], who became her friend, dance teacher, and mentor.{{sfn|Eichenbaum|2011|p=143}} Winters cast her in many of his early movies and projects.{{cite web|url=http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|title=Teri Garr - My Life So Far|work=Ability Magazine|access-date=April 7, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220532/http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|archivedate=September 27, 2007|df=mdy-all}} Garr began as a background [[Go-go dancing|go-go dancer]] in uncredited roles in youth-oriented films and TV shows choreographed by Winters,{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0935916|title=David Winters biodata|website=IMDb.com|publisher=Internet Movie Database|access-date=September 6, 2017}} including ''[[Pajama Party (film)|Pajama Party]]'' (a [[beach party film]]), the ''[[T.A.M.I. Show]]'', ''[[Shindig!]]'', ''[[Shivaree (TV series)|Shivaree]]'', ''[[Hullabaloo (TV series)|Hullabaloo]]'', ''[[Movin' with Nancy]]'', and nine Elvis Presley features (many of which were also choreographed by Winters, including Presley's most profitable film, ''[[Viva Las Vegas]]''.{{sfn|Leszcak|2014|p=52}} When asked in a magazine interview about how she landed jobs in so many Presley films, Garr answered, "One of the dancers in the road show of ''[[West Side Story]]'' ([[David Winters (choreographer)|David Winters]]) started to choreograph movies, and whatever job he got, I was one of the girls he'd hire. So he was chosen to do ''Viva Las Vegas''. That was my first movie."{{cite web|url=http://www.davidwinters.net/archives2.htm|date=2004|title=Talkin' 'bout my g-g-g-generation|website=David Winters.net|access-date=April 7, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040302004146/http://www.davidwinters.net/archives2.htm|archivedate=March 2, 2004|df=mdy-all}} She often appeared on television during this time, performing as a go-go dancer on several musical [[variety show]]s, along with friend [[Toni Basil]], such as ''[[Shindig!]]'' and ''[[Hullabaloo (TV series)|Hullabaloo]]''. In 1966 Garr made one appearance on ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]'' (episode 7, uncredited). In 1968, she appeared in both ''[[The Andy Griffith Show]]'' and ''[[Mayberry R.F.D.]]{{cite episode|season=01|number=12|series=[[Mayberry R.F.D.]]|date=1968}}'' and was in two episodes of ''[[It Takes a Thief (1968 TV series)|It Takes a Thief]]''. ===1968–1983: Film and television; critical acclaim=== Her first speaking role in a motion picture was a brief appearance as a [[damsel in distress]] in the [[The Monkees|Monkees]] film ''[[Head (film)|Head]]'' (1968), written by [[Jack Nicholson]]; Garr obtained the role after meeting Nicholson in an acting class. "He wrote the script for ''Head'', so all of us in the class got little tiny parts in the movie," she recalled. "I was… Who was I? Oh yes, I was the girl dying of a snakebite, who falls off the Calistoga wagon and says, "Quick, suck it before the venom reaches my heart!"" The same year, she was featured as secretary Roberta Lincoln in the ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' episode "[[Assignment: Earth]]", designed as a [[Backdoor pilots|backdoor pilot]] episode for a new series which was not commissioned. In the early 1970s, she was a regular cast member on ''[[The Sonny and Cher Comedy Hour]]'', dancing and acting in comedy sketches.{{sfn|Lisanti|2015|p=134}} Garr appeared in a string of highly successful films in the mid-to-late 1970s, including a supporting role in [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s thriller ''[[The Conversation]]'' (1974).{{cite web|work=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]]|url=https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/persondetails/167050?sid=86bc0b55-e62a-4942-8cd3-167717896713&sr=2.7823553&cp=1&pos=0&cxt=Cast2|title=Teri Garr Filmography|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021050413/https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/persondetails/167050?sid=86bc0b55-e62a-4942-8cd3-167717896713&sr=2.7823553&cp=1&pos=0&cxt=Cast2|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} This was followed with her role as Inga, an assistant to Dr. Frederick Frankenstein, in the [[Mel Brooks]] [[comedy horror|horror comedy]] ''[[Young Frankenstein]]'' (1974), which marked a career breakthrough.{{cite web|work=[[Paper (magazine)|Paper]]|url=http://www.papermag.com/talking-young-frankenstein-with-teri-garr-1425479181.html|title=Talking Young Frankenstein With Teri Garr|author=Murrin, Tom|date=September 30, 2008|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021232045/http://www.papermag.com/talking-young-frankenstein-with-teri-garr-1425479181.html|archive-date=October 21, 2018|publisher=Paper Communications|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} She then appeared in [[Steven Spielberg]]'s [[science fiction]] film ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' (1977) as the wife of [[Richard Dreyfuss]]'s character; in ''[[Oh, God! (film)|Oh, God!]]'' (1977) as the wife of [[John Denver]]'s character; and the drama ''[[The Black Stallion (film)|The Black Stallion]]'' (1979). In 1978, Garr appeared [[Off-Broadway theater|Off-Broadway]] in a production of ''One Crack Out'' by Canadian playwright David French, playing the wife of Charlie, a pool hustler in [[Toronto]].{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Stage: Phoenix's ‘One Crack Out’|date=January 17, 1978|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1978/01/17/archives/stage-phoenixs-one-crack-out-david-frenchs-drama-shows-climactic.html|author=Eder, Richard|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022021444/https://www.nytimes.com/1978/01/17/archives/stage-phoenixs-one-crack-out-david-frenchs-drama-shows-climactic.html|archive-date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Richard Eder of ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted that Garr "manages an attractive uncertainty and devotion as Charlie's wife." In 1982, she starred opposite [[Dustin Hoffman]] in the comedy ''[[Tootsie]]'' (1982), playing an actress whose actor friend (Hoffman) disguises himself as a woman to further his career.{{cite web|work=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]]|url=https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/55197|title=Tootsie (1982)|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021232906/https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/55197|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} For her role, she was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]]. She then appeared in the comedy ''[[Mr. Mom]]'' (1983) as the wife of [[Michael Keaton]]'s character, followed by a supporting role in [[Martin Scorsese]]'s ''[[After Hours (film)|After Hours]]'' (1985). ===1984–2007: Later work and television=== [[File:TeriGarr HectorElizondo.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Garr and [[Hector Elizondo]] on the set of ''[[Perfect Alibi (1995 film)|Perfect Alibi]]'' with director [[Kevin Meyer]]]] She had a recurring role on ''[[McCloud (TV series)|McCloud]]'', and appeared on ''[[M*A*S*H (TV series)|M*A*S*H]]'', ''[[The Bob Newhart Show]]'', ''[[The Odd Couple (1970 TV series)|The Odd Couple]]'', ''[[Maude (TV series)|Maude]]'', ''[[Barnaby Jones]]'', and ''[[Paul Sand in Friends and Lovers]]''. She hosted ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' three times (in 1980, 1983, and 1985), and was a frequent visitor on ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/teri-garr/credits/176448/|work=[[TV Guide]]|title=Teri Garr Credits|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021231456/https://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/teri-garr/credits/176448/|archive-date=October 21, 2018|publisher=NTVB Media|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} As a recurring guest on ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'', she was renowned for her unscripted banter with [[David Letterman]],{{cite web|work=[[Deseret News]]|location=Salt Lake City, Utah|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/551865/Letterman-invites-Teri-Garr-back---finally.html|title=Letterman invites Teri Garr back - finally|author=Pierce, Scott D.|date=March 28, 1997|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021230926/https://www.deseretnews.com/article/551865/Letterman-invites-Teri-Garr-back---finally.html|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} who once goaded her into showering in his office while the camera rolled.{{cite news|url=http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|title=Teri Garr–My Life So Far|publisher=Ability Magazine|year=2007|issue=1|accessdate=June 21, 2007|first=Jacob|last=Wascalus|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220532/http://www.abilitymagazine.com/Garr/teri_garr.html|archivedate=September 27, 2007|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/show_info/pants/Letterman25.pdf|title=David Letterman - 25 Years and Still Going Strong |publisher=[[CBS]]|accessdate=June 21, 2007| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070620154551/http://www.cbs.com/latenight/lateshow/show_info/pants/Letterman25.pdf|archivedate=June 20, 2007}} In 1989, she appeared in ''[[Let It Ride (film)|Let It Ride]]'', also opposite Dreyfuss. In the late-1990s, Garr landed a role as recurring character [[Phoebe Abbott]] in ''[[Friends]]'', the estranged birth mother of [[Phoebe Buffay]].{{cite web|work=Bustle|url=https://www.bustle.com/articles/136721-what-the-parents-from-friends-look-like-now-vs-their-90s-looks|title=What The Parents From 'Friends' Look Like Now Vs. Their '90s Looks|author=Callegari, Caitlyn|date=January 20, 2016|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021231259/https://www.bustle.com/articles/136721-what-the-parents-from-friends-look-like-now-vs-their-90s-looks|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Garr's career began to slow in the late-1990s after she was informed by a [[neurologist]] that symptoms she had been experiencing for many years were those of [[multiple sclerosis]].{{cite web|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|url=https://people.com/archive/restricted-teri-garrs-odyssey-vol-64-no-19/|date=November 7, 2005|title=RESTRICTED: Teri Garr's Odyssey|author=''People'' Staff|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022000326/https://people.com/archive/restricted-teri-garrs-odyssey-vol-64-no-19/|archive-date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} In film, she appeared in minor supporting roles, including portraying a witch in the children's film ''[[Casper Meets Wendy]]'' (1998), and as the mother of [[Michelle Williams (actress)|Michelle Williams]] in the political comedy ''[[Dick (film)|Dick]]'' (1999).{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Holden, Stephen|author-link=Stephen Holden|title=FILM REVIEW; That Gap in the Nixon Tapes? Maybe a Teen-Age Cry of Love|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/04/movies/film-review-that-gap-in-the-nixon-tapes-maybe-a-teen-age-cry-of-love.html|date=August 4, 1999|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022023501/https://www.nytimes.com/1999/08/04/movies/film-review-that-gap-in-the-nixon-tapes-maybe-a-teen-age-cry-of-love.html|archive-date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} This was followed by an uncredited role in [[Terry Zwigoff]]'s ''[[Ghost World (film)|Ghost World]]'' (2001).{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2001/film/awards/ghost-world-1200468688/|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|publisher=[[Penske Media Corporation]]|title=Ghost World|author=Eisner, Ken|date=June 21, 2001}} She also provided the voice of Mary McGinnis in two [[Batman]] animated films: ''[[Batman Beyond: The Movie]]'' (1999), and ''[[Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker]]'' (2000). Garr returned to the stage in 2000, appearing in numerous Off-Broadway performances of ''[[The Vagina Monologues]]'' throughout the fall of that year opposite [[Sanaa Lathan]] and [[Julianna Margulies]].{{cite web|work=[[Playbill]]|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/shields-ruehl-and-garr-booked-for-obs-monologues-com-90935|title=Shields, Ruehl and Garr Booked for OB's Monologues|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022021858/http://www.playbill.com/article/shields-ruehl-and-garr-booked-for-obs-monologues-com-90935|archive-date=October 22, 2018|date=July 31, 2000|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} She subsequently had minor supporting roles in the Christmas comedy film ''[[Unaccompanied Minors]]'' (2006),{{cite web|work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]]|url=https://www.today.com/popculture/teri-garr-writes-about-movies-men-ms-wbna15413628|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022001249/https://www.today.com/popculture/teri-garr-writes-about-movies-men-ms-wbna15413628|archive-date=October 22, 2018|title=Teri Garr writes about movies, men and MS|date=October 25, 2006|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} and the independent comedies ''[[Expired]]'' and ''[[Kabluey]]'' (both 2007). ===Retirement=== Garr has not acted in films or television since 2007, though she did publicly appear at the 19th Annual Race to Erase MS ([[multiple sclerosis]]) event in 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/teri-garr-and-nancy-davis-attend-the-19th-annual-race-to-news-photo/144765017|title=19th Annual Race To Erase MS|publisher=[[Getty Images]]|date=May 18, 2012|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} In 2006, Garr published an [[autobiography]] detailing her career and health struggles following her diagnosis with [[multiple sclerosis]], titled ''Speedbumps: Flooring It Through Hollywood''.{{cite web|work=[[Houston Chronicle]]|url=https://www.chron.com/entertainment/article/Humor-keeps-comedy-actress-Teri-Garr-afloat-1664453.php|location=Houston, Texas|title=Humor keeps comedy actress Teri Garr afloat|date=April 19, 2008|access-date=October 21, 2018}} Garr appeared on ''[[The Moth]] Radio Hour'' broadcast of December 9, 2009 to tell a humorous reminiscence entitled "Wake Up Call".{{cite web|url=https://themoth.org/stories/wake-up-call|title=Wake Up Call|publisher=''[[The Moth]]''|accessdate=January 13, 2018|date=December 9, 2009}} ==Personal life== [[File:Teri Garr at the AIDS Project Los Angeles (APLA) benefit cropped.jpg|thumb|upright|Garr at the [[AIDS Project Los Angeles]] (APLA) benefit, September 1990]] In the early-1980s, Garr was in a four-year relationship with film executive [[Roger Birnbaum]].{{cite web|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|url=https://people.com/archive/teri-garr-is-no-dizzy-blonde-but-acting-like-one-in-tootsie-hasnt-hurt-vol-19-no-7/|title=Teri Garr Is No Dizzy Blonde, but Acting Like One in Tootsie Hasn't Hurt|author=Bricker, Rebecca|date=February 21, 1983|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022001534/https://people.com/archive/teri-garr-is-no-dizzy-blonde-but-acting-like-one-in-tootsie-hasnt-hurt-vol-19-no-7/|archive-date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} After separating from Birnbaum, Garr was in a seven-year relationship with David Kipper, a physician, whom she was introduced to by [[Carrie Fisher]].{{sfn|Garr|2006|pages=141, 152–155}} Garr has one daughter, Molly O'Neil, born in November 1993, who she adopted with her husband, contractor John O'Neil; the two were there on the day their adopted daughter was born. Garr and O'Neil divorced in 1996.{{cite web|work=[[Deseret News]]|location=Salt Lake City, Utah|url=https://www.deseretnews.com/article/470410/ACTRESS-WANTS-A-DIVORCE---ALONG-WITH-ALL-EARNINGS.html|title=ACTRESS WANTS A DIVORCE - ALONG WITH ALL EARNINGS|date=February 8, 1996|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021233155/https://www.deseretnews.com/article/470410/ACTRESS-WANTS-A-DIVORCE---ALONG-WITH-ALL-EARNINGS.html|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} In July 1990, a Los Angeles County judge ordered a female [[stalking|stalker]] of Garr's to cease contacting her, as well remain 100 yards away Garr, her home, and her work locations for three years.{{cite web|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 17, 1990|title=Judge Orders Woman to Leave Actress Alone|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021233429/http://articles.latimes.com/1990-07-17/local/me-119_1_judge-orders-woman|archive-date=October 21, 2018|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-07-17/local/me-119_1_judge-orders-woman|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ===Health issues=== In October 2002, Garr publicly confirmed that she had been diagnosed with [[multiple sclerosis]].{{cite web|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/News/10/08/teri.garr.ms|title=Teri Garr reveals she has multiple sclerosis|date=October 9, 2002|accessdate=June 5, 2007|work=CNN|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AGWfZ8xB?url=http://archives.cnn.com/2002/SHOWBIZ/News/10/08/teri.garr.ms|archivedate=August 28, 2012|df=mdy-all}} After years of uncertainty and secrecy surrounding her diagnosis, Garr explained her reasons for deciding to go public: "I'm telling my story for the first time so I can help people. I can help people know they aren't alone and tell them there are reasons to be optimistic because, today, treatment options are available." In interviews, she has commented that she first started noticing symptoms while in New York filming ''[[Tootsie]]'' around 1982. After disclosing her condition, she became a National Ambassador for the [[National Multiple Sclerosis Society]] and National Chair for the Society's Women Against MS program (WAMS).{{cite web|url=http://www.news-medical.net/?id=1021|title=Actress Teri Garr named as multiple sclerosis national chairwoman|accessdate=June 5, 2007|date=April 29, 2004|work=News-Medical.net}} In November 2005, Garr was honored as the society's Ambassador of the Year. The same year, she revealed her treatment regimen for the disease, which included regular [[steroid]] injections to help manage symptoms. ''Closer'' reported in 2015 that she credited her positive attitude and support of her family as helping her fight the disease.{{cite web|url=http://www.closerweekly.com/posts/exclusive-teri-garr-battles-multiple-sclerosis-stays-positive-67607|title=Teri Garr Battles Multiple Sclerosis With a Positive Outlook With the Help of Her Family|work=Closer Weekly|date=August 23, 2015|accessdate=December 11, 2016}} In December 2006, Garr suffered a ruptured [[brain aneurysm]].{{cite web|first=Michelle|last=Tan|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20005817,00.html|title=Teri Garr Recovering from Brain Aneurysm|accessdate=June 5, 2007|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=January 2, 2007}} The aneurysm left Garr in a [[coma]] for weeks,,{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/HEALTH/conditions/08/06/garr.aneurysm/index.html|work=[[CNN]]|title=Teri Garr: Post-aneurysm, comedy keeps her going|author=Gajilan, A. Chris|date=August 6, 2008|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021101200/http://edition.cnn.com/2008/HEALTH/conditions/08/06/garr.aneurysm/index.html|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 21, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} but after therapy, she regained speech and motor skills, and, in 2008 appeared on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' to promote ''[[Expired]]'', a 2007 film in which she played a set of twins.{{cite web|title=David Letterman-Teri Garr-June-19-2008|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XYq5fk69dIY|publisher=YouTube|accessdate= November 7, 2017}} ==Philanthropy== In March 1988, Garr was arrested for [[trespassing]] in [[Mercury, Nevada]] during a protest against [[nuclear weapons testing]] in the area.{{Cite web|work=[[United Press International]]|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1988/03/13/Nations-nuclear-weapons-center-penetrated/9515574232400/|title=Nation's nuclear weapons center penetrated|date=March 13, 1988|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181021233717/https://www.upi.com/Archives/1988/03/13/Nations-nuclear-weapons-center-penetrated/9515574232400/|archive-date=October 21, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} Garr has contributed to charity events for [[The Trevor Project]], a non-profit [[LGBT|gay]] youth [[suicide prevention]] organization.{{cite web|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/Wisecracking-Teri-Garr-At-Gay-Hotline-Benefit-2692905.php|title=Wisecracking Teri Garr At Gay Hotline Benefit / Olivia Newton John in tears at fund-raiser|author=Smith, Liz|date=December 5, 2000|access-date=October 21, 2018|location=San Francisco, California}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/nov/29/news/wk-sun29|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 29, 2001|title=All day Art|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022023932/http://articles.latimes.com/2001/nov/29/news/wk-sun29|archive-date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ==Legacy== Garr has been described as a "comedic legend." In 1982, film critic [[Pauline Kael]] described her as "the funniest neurotic dizzy dame on the screen." She has been named as an influence by numerous performers, including [[Jenna Fischer]]{{cite web|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/04/funny_fischer200804#~o|title=Chicks with Schticks|author=Windolf, Jim|date=April 2008|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022024536/https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2008/04/funny_fischer200804%23~o#~o|archive-date=October 22, 2018|publisher=[[Condé Nast]]|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} and [[Tina Fey]].{{cite web|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|publisher=Onion, Inc.|title=Teri Garr|date=July 22, 2008|author=O'Neal, Sean|url=https://film.avclub.com/teri-garr-1798214431|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181022025128/https://film.avclub.com/teri-garr-1798214431|archive-date=October 22, 2018|access-date=October 22, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} ==Accolades== {| class="wikitable" style="width:70%;" |- ! width=2%|Year ! style="width:23%"|Institution ! style="width:20%;"| Category ! style="width:26%;"| Nominated work ! style="width:10%;"| Result ! width=3%|{{Abbr|Ref.|Reference(s)}} |- | 1978 || [[Saturn Awards]] || Best Supporting Actress || ''[[Close Encounters of the Third Kind]]'' || {{nominated}} || |- | 1983 || [[Academy Awards]] || [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] || ''[[Tootsie]]'' || {{nominated}} || align=center|{{cite web|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/jun/30/entertainment/et-garr30|date=June 30, 2008|title=Garr back on her feet, back on the big screen|author=King, Susan|access-date=October 21, 2018}} |- | 1983 || [[National Society of Film Critics]] || [[National Society of Film Critics Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] || ''Tootsie'' || {{center|Third place}} || |- | 1983 || [[CableACE Awards]] || Best Dramatic Actress || ''[[Faerie Tale Theatre]]''
{{small|(Episode: "The Tale of the Frog Prince")}} || {{nominated}} || |- | 1984 || [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA Awards]] || [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Supporting Role|Best Supporting Actress]] || ''Tootsie'' || {{nominated}} || align=center|{{cite web|url=http://awards.bafta.org/award/1984/film|work=[[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]]|title=Film in 1984|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130502223447/http://awards.bafta.org/award/1984/film|archive-date=May 2, 2013|access-date=October 21, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} |- | 1994 || [[National Board of Review]] || [[National Board of Review Award for Best Cast|Best Acting Ensemble]] || ''[[Prêt-à-Porter (film)|Prêt-à-Porter]]'' || {{won}} || align=center|{{cite web|work=[[National Board of Review]]|series=Archive|url=http://www.nationalboardofreview.org/award-names/best-ensemble-cast/|title=Best Ensemble Cast|archive-url=https://archive.today/20131007232620/http://www.nationalboardofreview.org/award-names/best-ensemble-cast/|archive-date=October 7, 2013|access-date=October 21, 2018|dead-url=no|df=mdy-all}} |} ==Filmography== {{Main|Teri Garr filmography}} ==Notes== {{noteslist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Works cited== *{{cite Connecticut|year=2011|isbn=978-0-819-57165-6|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Garr|first=Teri|year=2006|title=Speedbumps: Flooring It Through Hollywood|location=New <center> {{hlist |[[#1600s|1600s]] |[[#1740s|1740s]] |[[#1760s|1760s]] |[[#1770s|1770s]] |[[#1780s|1780s]] |[[#1790s|1790s]] |[[#1800s|1800s]] |[[#1810s|1810s]] |[[#1820s|1820s]] |[[#1830s|1830s]] |[[#1840s|1840s]] |[[#1850s|1850s]] |[[#1860s|1860s]] |[[#1870s|1870s]] |[[#1880s|1880s]] |[[#1890s|1890s]] |[[#1900s|1900s]] |[[#1910s|1910s]] |[[#1920s|1920s]] |[[#1930s|1930s]] |[[#1940s|1940s]] |[[#1950s|1950s]] |[[#1960s|1960s]] |[[#1970s|1970s]] |[[#1980s|1980s]] |[[#2000s|2000s]] |[[#2010s|2010s]]}} </center>

;1 May 1886 (United States) :Workers protested in the streets to demand the universal adoption of the [[eight-hour day]]. Hundreds of thousands of American workers had joined the [[Knights of Labor]]. The movement ultimately failed.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:JMRusk.jpg|thumb|left|Representative Jeremiah M. Rusk]]
;1 May 1886 (United States) :[[Bay View Tragedy]]: About 2,000 Polish workers walked off their jobs and gathered at St. Stanislaus Church in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], angrily denouncing the [[eight-hour day|ten-hour workday]]. The protesters marched through the city, calling on other workers to join them. All but one factory was closed down as sixteen thousand protesters gathered at Rolling Mills. Wisconsin Governor [[Jeremiah Rusk]] called the state militia. The militia camped out at the mill while workers slept in nearby fields. On the morning of 5 May, as protesters chanted for the eight-hour workday, General Treaumer ordered his men to shoot into the crowd, some of whom were carrying sticks, bricks, and scythes, leaving seven dead at the scene, including a child.<ref name="WLHS">[http://www.wisconsinlaborhistory.org/bayview.html Wisconsin Labor History Society: Bay View Story] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051108103123/http://www.wisconsinlaborhistory.org/bayview.html |date=8 November 2005 }}</ref><ref name="LttP">[http://linkstothepast.com/milwaukee/bayviewmassacre.html Bay View Massacre, Milwaukee County Genealogy]</ref>
:The ''[[Milwaukee Journal]]'' reported that eight more would die within twenty-four hours, adding that Governor Rusk was to be commended for his quick action in the matter.

;4 May 1886 (United States) :Anarchist rally lead to the [[Haymarket Riot]] in Chicago, [[Illinois]], the origin of international [[May Day]] observances.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;22 November 1887 (United States) :In the [[Thibodaux massacre]] in [[Thibodaux, Louisiana]] a local militia, aided by bands of "prominent citizens," shot at least 35 unarmed black sugar workers striking to gain a dollar-per-day wage, and lynched two strike leaders.
;1887 (United States) :Seven of the [[Haymarket Riot]] bombing defendants sentenced to death, of which five are executed.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1887 (United States) :[[Port of New York Longshoremen's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:Union Labor Campaign Poster 1888.jpg|thumb|alt=1888 Union Labor Poster |Union Labor Party campaign poster (1888)]]
;June 1888 (United Kingdom) :The [[London matchgirls strike of 1888]] was a [[Industrial action|strike]] of the women and [[teenage]] girls working at the [[Bryant and May Factory, Bow|Bryant and May Factory]] in [[Bow, London|Bow]], London. The strike was prompted by the poor working conditions in the [[match]] factory, including fourteen-hour work days, poor pay, excessive fines, and the severe health complications of working with yellow (or white) [[phosphorus]], such as [[phossy jaw]].
;1888 (United States) :United States enacted first federal labor relations law; the law applied only to railroads.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1888 (United States) :[[International Association of Machinists]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1888 (United States) :[[Burling Railroad Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1888 (United States) :[[Cincinnati Shoemakers' Lockout]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1889 (United States) :[[Baseball Players' Revolt]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1889 (United States) :[[Fall River, Massachusetts, Textile Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1889 (Europe) :The [[Second International]] is founded. Declaration of 1 May as [[International Workers Day]].
===1890s===
;1890 (United States) :[[United Mine Workers of America]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1890 (United States) :[[United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners of America]] Strike occurred; the union demanded an eight-hour work day.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;25 July 1890 (United States) :New York garment workers won the right to unionize after a seven-month strike. They secured agreements for a closed shop, and firing of all [[strikebreakers]].
;1891 (United States) :[[Savannah, Georgia, Black Labourers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1891 (United States) :[[Tennessee Miners' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:Longshoremen-1901.jpg|thumb|200px|alt=International Longshoremen's Union banner|International Longshoremen's Union banner]]
;1892 (United States) :[[International Longshoremen's Association]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1892 (United States) :[[International Seamen's Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1892 (United States) :[[New Orleans General Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;6 July 1892 (United States) :[[Homestead Strike]]:<ref name="fillippelli_p022" /> [[Pinkerton National Detective Agency|Pinkerton]] Guards, trying to pave the way for the introduction of [[strikebreakers]], opened fire on striking Carnegie mill steel-workers in [[Homestead, Pennsylvania]]. In the ensuing battle, three Pinkertons surrendered and were set upon and beaten by a mob of townspeople, most of them women. Seven guards and eleven strikers and spectators were shot to death.<ref name="yellen" />
;11 July 1892 (United States) :[[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor strike of 1892]]: Striking miners in [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho]] dynamited the Frisco Mill, leaving it in ruins.
;1893 (United States) :[[American Railway Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1893 (United States) :[[Western Federation of Miners]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1893 (United States) :Federal court in Louisiana rules that the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]] applies to unions and finds that [[Secondary action|sympathy strikes]] restrain trade.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1893 (United States) :[[National Civic Federation]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
; 1893 (United States) :Unions helped win the passage of the Safety Appliance Act. Among other things, the Act outlawed the "old man-killer link and pin coupler" by railroads.
;1894 (United Kingdom) :''[[History of Trade Unionism]]'', the influential book by [[Sidney James Webb, 1st Baron Passfield|Sidney]] and [[Beatrice Webb]] is first published.
;1894 (United States) :[[Coxey's Army]] marched on Washington, D.C.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;7 February 1894 (United States) :In [[Cripple Creek, Colorado]], miners [[Cripple Creek miners' strike of 1894|went on strike]] when mine owners announced an increase from eight to ten hours per day, with no increase in wages.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" /> This strike marked perhaps the only time in American history that a state militia was called out to protect miners from sheriff's deputies.
;21 April – June 1894 (United States) :[[Bituminous Coal Miners' Strike of 1894]] -- A two-month nationwide strike by miners of hard coal in the United States. This unsuccessful strike almost destroyed the [[United Mine Workers]] union.
[[File:Pullman-strike.djvu|thumb|alt=Pullman-strike|Pullman strikers outside Arcade Building in Pullman, Chicago. The Illinois National Guard can be seen guarding the building during the Pullman Railroad Strike in 1894.]]
;11 May – 10 July 1894 (United States) :[[Pullman Strike]]: A nation-wide strike against the Pullman Company begins with a wildcat walkout<ref name="fillippelli_p022" /> on 11 May after wages are drastically reduced. On 5 July, the 1892 World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago's [[Jackson Park (Chicago)|Jackson Park]] was set ablaze, and seven buildings were burned to the ground. The mobs burned and looted railroad cars and fought police in the streets, until 10 July, when 14,000 federal and state troops finally succeeded in putting down the strike, killing 34 [[American Railway Union]] members. Leaders of the strike, including [[Eugene Debs]], were imprisoned for violating injunctions, causing disintegration of the union.<ref name="yellen" />
;1895 (France) :The [[Confédération Générale du Travail]] (CGT), was formed. This French union is the oldest confederation still in existence.
;April 1895 (United States) :[[American Industrial Union]] established by former American Railway Union Vice President [[George W. Howard]]. The union proves to be short-lived, disappearing in the second half of 1896.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/15309045/american_industrial_union_organization/ "American Industrial Union: Organization with Unlimited Aims Begins Its Existence,"] ''Chicago Inter Ocean,'' April 22, 1895, pg. 5.</ref>
;June 1895 (United States) :[[U.S. Supreme Court]] rules in ''In re Debs'' to uphold an injunction against the [[Pullman Strike]]rs on the grounds that the federal government is empowered to regulate interstate commerce.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1895 (United States) :[[Socialist Trade and Labor Alliance]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1895 (United States) :[[Haverhill, Massachusetts, Show Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;21 September 1896 (United States) :The state militia was sent to [[Leadville]], Colorado to [[Leadville Colorado, Miners' Strike|break a miner's strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:Lattimer massacre.jpg|thumb|Lattimer massacre: Mine workers began their protest march near Harwood and many were eventually killed by the Luzerne County sheriff in Lattimer.]]
;10 September 1897 (United States) :[[Lattimer massacre]]: 19 unarmed striking coal miners and mine workers were killed and 36 wounded by a posse organized by the Luzerne County sheriff for refusing to disperse near [[Hazleton, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="fillippelli_p022" /> The strikers, most of whom were shot in the back, were originally brought in as strike-breakers, but later organized themselves.
;1898 (United States) :The Erdman Act was passed providing for mediation and voluntary arbitration on the railroads.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" /> It made it a criminal offense for railroads to dismiss employees or to discriminate against prospective employees because of their union membership or activity. It provided legal protection of employees' rights to membership in a labor union, a limit on the use of injunctions in labor disputes, lawful status of picketing and other union activities, and requirement of employers to bargain collectively. Subsequently, a portion of the [[Erdman Act]], which would have made it a criminal offense for railroads to dismiss employees or discriminate against prospective employees based on their union activities, was declared invalid by the [[United States Supreme Court]].
;1898 (United States) :[[American Labor Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
;1898 (United States) :[[Marlboro, Massachusetts, Shoe Workers' Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p022" />
[[File:Miner extracting ore from Bunker Hill mine.jpg|thumb|Miner extracting ore from Bunker Hill mine]]
;1899 (United States) :Miners in Idaho [[Coeur d'Alene, Idaho labor confrontation of 1899|dynamite a mill]] in retaliation for the [[Bunker Hill Mining Company]] firing 17 union members.<ref name="fillippelli_p023">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xxiii}}</ref>
;1899 (United States) :[[Teamsters Union|Brotherhood of Teamsters]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1899 (United States) :[[Buffalo, New York, Grain Shovelers's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1899 (United States) :[[Cleveland, Ohio, Street Railway Worker's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1899 (United States) :[[Newsboys Strike of 1899]] occurred in New York City.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />

===1900s=== ;1900 (United States) :[[International Ladies' Garment Workers Union]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1900 (United States) :[[Anthracite Coal Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1900 (United States) :[[Machinists' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />

;1901 (United States) :[[Machinists' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1901 (United States) :[[National Cash Register Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1901 (United States) :[[San Francisco Restaurant Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1901 (United States) :[[U.S. Steel Recognition Strike of 1901]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
[[File:Coal miners in Hazleton PA 1900.jpg|thumb|alt=Coal miners in Hazelton, Pennsylvania, 1902|Coal miners in Hazelton, Pennsylvania, 1902]] [[File:Wrau-coal-strike-commission.jpg|thumb|alt=Wrau coal strike commission, 1902 |Anthracite Coal Strike Commission Appointed 1902 by President Roosevelt, a stereo card of the commission appointed by Theodore Roosevelt to resolve the [[Coal Strike of 1902]].]]
;15 May 1902 (United States) :[[Coal Strike of 1902]]<ref name="fillippelli_p023" /> -- [[United Mine Workers of America]] in the [[anthracite coal]] fields of eastern [[Pennsylvania]] struck in seven counties, from May through October. The strike caused a nationwide coal shortage. [[President of the United States|President]] [[Theodore Roosevelt]] imposed the first mediated agreement of its kind.
;1902 (United States) :[[Chicago Teamsters' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1903 (United States) :[[U.S. Department of Commerce and Labor]] created.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1903 (United States) :[[Women's Trade Union League]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1903 (United States) :[[Oxnard Strike of 1903|Oxnard, California, Sugar Beet Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1903 (United States) :[[Carbon County Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;23 November 1903 (United States) :[[Colorado Labor Wars]]: Troops were dispatched to [[Cripple Creek, Colorado|Cripple Creek]], Colorado to defeat a strike by the [[Western Federation of Miners]],<ref name="fillippelli_p023" /> with the specific purpose of driving the union out of the district. The strike had begun in the ore mills earlier in 1903, and then spread to the mines.
[[File:Mother Jones 02.jpg|thumb|alt=Mother Jones 02 |American labor activist Mother Jones (1837–1930)]]
;July 1903 (United States) :Labor organizer [[Mary Harris Jones|Mary Harris "Mother" Jones]] leads child workers in demanding a 55-hour work week.
;1904 (United States) :[[New York City Interborough Rapid Transit Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1904 (United States) :[[United Packinghouse Workers of America]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1904 (United States) :[[Santa Fe Railroad Shopmen's Strike]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;8 June 1904 (United States) :A battle between the Colorado Militia and striking miners at Dunnville ended with six union members dead and 15 taken prisoner. Seventy-nine of the strikers were deported to Kansas two days later.
;1905 (United States) :[[Industrial Workers of the World]] founded in [[Chicago, Illinois]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;17 April 1905 (United States) :The Supreme Court held in [[Lochner v. New York]] that a maximum hours law for New York bakery workers was unconstitutional under the due process clause of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|14th amendment]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1906 (United States) :An eight-hour workday is widely adopted in the printing industry.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1907 (United States) :[[Goldfield, Nevada#Labor relations during the boom years|Goldfield, Nevada, Miners' Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
[[File:1908-WTUL-laborday.jpg|thumb|alt=Labor Day Parade, float of Women's Trade Union League, New York, 1908 September 7 |Labor Day Parade, float of Women's Trade Union League, New York, 1908 September 7]]
;1908 (United States) :The Federal Employers' Liability Act was passed. Also that year, the [[Adair v. United States|Erdman Act]] was further weakened by the Supreme Court when Section 10, related to use of "yellow dog" contracts, was declared unconstitutional (see 1898).<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1908 (United States) :[[U.S. Supreme Court]] rules in ''Danbury Hatters Case'' that a boycott launched by the [[United Hatters Union]] is a conspiracy in restraint of trade under the [[Sherman Antitrust Act]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1908 (United States) :[[U.S. Supreme Court]] rules in ''Muller vs. Oregon'' that an Oregon law that limited the working hours for women was unconstitutional.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1908 (United States) :[[Free speech fights#.22Free speech fights.22 and the IWW|IWW Free Speech Fight]] began in [[Missoula, Montana]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1909 (United States) :[[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1909 (United States) :[[Free speech fights#.22Free speech fights.22 and the IWW|IWW Free Speech Fight]] began in [[Spokane, Washington]].<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
[[File:McKees-constables-1909.jpg|thumb|alt=McKees constables on horseback, 1909|Pennsylvania constabulary, mounted on horses, at McKee's Rock, circa 1909]]
;1909 (United States) :[[Pressed Steel Car Strike of 1909|McKees Rocks, Pennsylvania, Steel Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p023" />
;1909 (United States) :[[Watertown, Connecticut, Arsenal Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xxiv}}</ref>
[[File:Ladies tailors strikers.jpg|thumb|alt=Ladies tailors strikers|Two women strikers on picket line during the "Uprising of the 20,000", garment workers strike, New York City. Strikes, ladies tailors, N.Y., Feb. 1910, picket girls on duty]]
;22 November 1909 (United States) :The [[New York shirtwaist strike of 1909]] (Uprising of the 20,000) began. Female garment workers went on strike in New York; many were arrested. A judge told those arrested: "You are on strike against God".<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
===1910s=== ;1910 (United States) :[[Bethlehem Steel Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1910 (United States) :[[1910 Cloakmakers' Strike|Cloakmakers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1910 (United States) :[[1910 Chicago Garment Workers' Strike|Chicago Clothing Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1910 (United States) :The 1910 Accident Reports Act was passed and a 10-hour work day and standardization of rates of pay and working conditions were won by the Railway Brotherhoods.
:Union membership topped 8 million workers in 1910.
[[File:Photo-los-angeles-times-building-post-bombing.jpg|thumb|Rubble of the ''Los Angeles Times'' building in 1910]]
;1 October 1910 (United States) :The [[Los Angeles Times bombing]] killed twenty people and destroyed the building. Calling it "the crime of the century," the newspaper's owner [[Harrison Gray Otis (publisher)|Harrison Gray Otis]] blamed the bombing on the unions, a charge denied by unionists.
;25 December 1910 (United States)
{{Main|McNamara brothers}} :A dynamite bomb destroyed a portion of the [[Llewellyn Iron works]] in Los Angeles, where a strike was in progress. In April 1911 James McNamara and his brother John McNamara, secretary-treasurer of the [[International Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers]], were charged with the two crimes. James McNamara pleaded guilty to murder and John McNamara pleaded guilty to conspiracy in the dynamiting of the Llewellyn Iron Works.<ref name="gompers"/>
;1911 (United States) :The [[Locomotive Inspection Act]] passed. Four years later, the [[Hours of Service Act]] passed. The Railroad Brotherhoods had won an eight-hour day.
:The Supreme Court in ''[[Gompers v. Buck's Stove and Range Co.]]'' (221 U.S. 418) affirmed a lower court order for the AFL to stop interfering with Buck's Stove and Range Company's business or boycotting its products or distributors.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
:On 24 June 1912 in the second contempt trial, the defendants (Samuel Gompers, John Mitchell, and Frank Morrison) were again found guilty and sentenced to prison. The Supreme Court overturned the convictions because the new proceedings had not been instituted within the three-year statute of limitations (233 U.S. 604 1914).<ref name="gompers">[http://www.history.umd.edu/Gompers/fnnp.htm The Samuel Gompers Papers]</ref>
;1911 (United States) :[[Illinois Central and Harriman Line Rail Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1911 (United States) :[[Southern Lumber Operators' Lockout]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1911 (Wales) : Two men are shot dead by police during the [[Llanelli railway strike]] of August 1911, leading to rioting.
[[File:Image of Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire on March 25 - 1911.jpg|thumb|Image of Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire on 25 March 1911]]
;25 March 1911 (United States) :[[Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire]] -- The Triangle Shirtwaist Company, occupying the top three floors of a ten-story building in New York City, was consumed by fire. One hundred and forty-six people, mostly women and young girls working in sweatshop conditions, died.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1912 (United States) :Massachusetts passes the first minimum wage law for women and minors.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1912 (United States) :[[1912 Chicago newspaper strike|Chicago newspaper strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1912 (United States) :[[Fur Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1912 (United States) :[[Free speech fights|IWW Free Speech Fight]] occurred in [[San Diego, California]].<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1912 (United States) :[[New York City Hotel Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
[[File:1912 Lawrence Textile Strike 3.jpg|thumb|alt=Lawrence Textile Strike 3|Lawrence Textile Strike, 1912]] [[File:1912 Lawrence Textile Strike 2.jpg|thumb|alt=Lawrence Textile Strike 2|Flyer distributed in Lawrence, September 1912. The Lawrence Textile Strike was a strike of immigrant workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts in 1912 led by the Industrial Workers of the World.]]
;January–March 1912 (United States) :[[Lawrence Textile Strike]] in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]], often known as the "[[Bread and Roses]]" Strike. Dozens of different immigrant communities united under the leadership of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW) in a largely successful strike led to a large extent by women. The strike is credited with inventing the moving picket line, a tactic devised to keep strikers from being arrested for loitering.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
:It also adopted a tactic used before in Europe, but never in the United States, of sending children to sympathizers in other cities when they could not be cared for by strike funds. On 24 February, women attempting to put their children on a train out of town were beaten by police, shocking the nation.<ref name="yellen">{{cite book | author=Yellen, Samuel | title=American Labor Struggles | publisher= Anchor Foundation | year= 1974 (1936) | isbn=0-913460-33-8}}</ref><ref name="watson">{{cite book | last = Watson | first = Bruce | year = 2005 | title = Bread and Roses | publisher = Viking | location = New York | isbn = 0-670-03397-9}}</ref>
;18 April 1912 (United States) :The National Guard was called out against striking [[West Virginia]] coal miners at the Paint Creek and Cabin Creek, West Virginia mines.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;7 July 1912 (United States) :Striking members of [[the Brotherhood of Timber Workers]] and supporters are involved in an armed confrontation with the Galloway Lumber Company and supporters in the [[Grabow Riot]], resulting in four deaths and 40 to 50 wounded.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1913 (United States) :[[U.S. Department of Labor]] established.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1913 (United States) :[[Machinists Strike and Boycott]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1913 (United States) :[[Michigan Copper Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1913 (United States) :[[Paterson, New Jersey, Textile Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1913 (United States) :[[Rubber Workers' Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1913 (United States) :[[Studebaker Motors Auto Workers' Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1913 (United States) :[[Wheatland Hop Riot|Wheatland, California, Hop Riot]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;11 June 1913 (United States) :Police shot three maritime workers (one of whom was killed) who were striking against the [[United Fruit Company]] in [[New Orleans]].
[[File:IWW demonstration NY 1914.jpg|thumb|alt=IWW demonstration, New York, 1914 |Industrial Workers of the World (IWW) demonstration in New York, 11 April 1914]]
;1914 (United States) :According to a report by the Commission on Industrial Relations, approximately 35,000 workers were killed in industrial accidents and 700,000 workers were injured in the U.S.
;1914 (United States) :U.S. Congress passes the [[Clayton Antitrust Act]] limiting the use of injunctions in labor disputes.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1914 (United States) :[[Amalgamated Clothing Workers]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1914 (United States) :[[Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills|Fulton Bag and Cotton Mill Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;5 January 1914 (United States) :The Ford Motor Company raised its basic wage from $2.40 for a nine-hour day to $5 for an [[eight-hour day]].
[[File:Joe hill002.jpg|thumb|[[Joe Hill]]]]
;14 January 1914 (United States) :Labor leader [[Joe Hill]] was arrested in [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]]. He was convicted on murder charges, and was executed 21 months later despite worldwide protests and two attempts to intervene by President [[Woodrow Wilson]]. In a letter to [[Bill Haywood]] shortly before his death he penned the famous words, "Don't mourn - organize!"
[[File:The Ludlow Massacre Memorial, April 20th, 1914, Colorado Coal Miners on Strike (3453614459).jpg|thumb|The Ludlow Massacre Memorial, 20 April 1914, Colorado Coal Miners on Strike (3453614459)]] [[File:Sympathy Labor Parade -- 1916 (LOC) (15112771653).jpg|thumb|A "Sympathy Labor Parade" in New York during the [[Minnesota Iron Range Strike]], 1916]]
;20 April 1914 (United States) :The "[[Ludlow Massacre]]." In an attempt to persuade strikers at Colorado's Ludlow Mine Field to return to work, company "guards," engaged by [[John D. Rockefeller, Jr.]] and other mine operators and sworn into the State Militia just for the occasion, attacked a union tent camp with machine guns, then set it afire. Five men, two women and 12 children died as a result.{{Ref|yellen}}{{Ref|Ludlow}}
;13 November 1914 (United States) :A [[Western Federation of Miners]] strike is crushed by the militia in [[Butte, Montana|Butte]], [[Montana]].
;1915 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] passed the [[La Follette Seamen's Act]] regulating working conditions for seamen.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1915 (United States) :[[Bayonne refinery strikes of 1915–1916]] against [[Standard Oil]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1915 (United States) :[[Youngstown, Ohio, Steel Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;19 January 1915 (United States) :Twenty rioting strikers were shot by factory guards at [[Roosevelt, New Jersey|Roosevelt]], [[New Jersey]].
;25 January 1915 (United States) :The Supreme Court upholds "yellow dog" contracts, which forbid membership in labor unions.
;1916 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] passed the [[Federal Child Labor Law]], which was later ruled unconstitutional.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] passed the [[Adamson Act]], which established an eight-hour workday for railroad workers.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[American Federation of Teachers]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[Arizona Copper Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[Minnesota Iron Range Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[1916 New York City Transit Strike|New York City Transit Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[New York Cloakmakers' Strike]]<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[San Francisco Open Shop Campaign]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;1916 (United States) :[[Bayonne refinery strikes of 1915–1916]] against [[Standard Oil]] continued.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
[[File:WP Thomas Mooney.jpg|thumb|alt=Thomas Mooney|Thomas Mooney (1882-1942), American socialist]]
;22 July 1916 (United States) :A bomb was set off during a "[[Preparedness Day]]" parade in San Francisco, killing 10 and injuring 40 more. [[Thomas Mooney|Thomas J. Mooney]], a labor organizer and [[Warren K. Billings]], a shoe worker, were convicted, but were both pardoned in 1939.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" />
;19 August 1916 (United States) :Strikebreakers hired by the Everett Mills owner [[Neil Jamison]] attacked and beat picketing strikers in Everett, Washington.<ref name="fillippelli_p024" /> Local police watched and refused to intervene.
:Three days later, twenty-two union men attempted to speak out at a local crossroads, but each was arrested; arrests and beatings of strikebreakers became common throughout the following months, and on 30 October vigilantes forced IWW speakers to run the gauntlet, subjecting them to whipping, tripping kicking, and impalement against a spiked cattle guard at the end of the gauntlet. In response, the [[Industrial Workers of the World|IWW]] called for a meeting on 5 November. When the union men arrived, they were fired on; seven people were killed, 50 were wounded, and an indeterminate number wound up missing.
;7 September 1916 (United States) :Federal employees win the right to receive [[Workers' compensation|Worker's Compensation insurance]].

;5 November 1916 (United States) :[[Everett massacre|The Everett Massacre]] (also known as Bloody Sunday) was an armed confrontation between local authorities and members of the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW) union, commonly called "Wobblies", which took place in Everett, Washington on Sunday, 5 November 1916. ;12 July 1917 (United States) :The [[Bisbee Deportation]]:<ref name="fillippelli_p025" /> After seizing the local Western Union telegraph office in order to cut off outside communication, several thousand armed vigilantes forced 1,185 men in [[Bisbee, Arizona]] into manure-laden boxcars and "deported" them to the New Mexico desert. The action was precipitated by a strike when workers' demands (including improvements to safety and working conditions at the local copper mines, an end to discrimination against labor organizations and unequal treatment of foreign and minority workers, and the institution of a [[living wage|fair wage]] system) went unmet. The "deportation" was organized by Sheriff Harry Wheeler. The incident was investigated months later by a Federal Mediation Commission set up by President [[Woodrow Wilson]]; the Commission found that no federal law applied, and referred the case to the State of Arizona, which failed to take any action, citing patriotism and support for the war as justification for the vigilantes' action.

;19 May 1920 (United States) :The [[Battle of Matewan]]. Despite efforts by police chief (and former miner) [[Sid Hatfield]] and Mayor Cabel Testerman to protect miners from interference in their union drive in [[Matewan, West Virginia]], [[Baldwin-Felts|Baldwin-Felts detectives]] hired by the local mining company arrived to evict miners and their families from the Stone Mountain Mine camp. A gun battle ensued, resulting in the deaths of 7 detectives, Mayor Testerman, and 2 miners. The movie [[Matewan]] is based on the event.
:[[Baldwin-Felts|Baldwin-Felts detectives]] assassinated [[Sid Hatfield]] 15 months later, sparking off an armed rebellion of 10,000 West Virginia coal miners at the "[[Battle of Blair Mountain]]," dubbed the "redneck war" and "the largest insurrection this country has had since the Civil War."
