;1941 (United States) :[[North American Aviation Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;20 June 1941 (United States) :[[Henry Ford]] recognizes the [[UAW]].
;15 December 1941 (United States) :The AFL pledges that there will be no strikes in defense-related industry plants for the duration of the war.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;1942 (United States) :[[National War Labor Board (1942–1945)|National War Labor Board]] was established; the NWLB established formula for wartime wage adjustments.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />[[File:Western Union A Labor Day Telegram To All Goodyearites - NARA - 533875.jpg|thumb|alt=Western Union A Labor Day Telegram to All Goodyearites |Western Union A Labor Day Telegram to All Goodyearites from Forrestal Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Patterson Under Secretary of War, 3 September 1942]]
;1942 (United States) :[[United Steel Workers of America]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
[[File:Kennedy tetlow lewis.jpg|thumb|alt=Kennedy tetlow lewis|War Labor Board anthracite hearing. John L. Lewis (right), President of the United Mine Workers (UMW), confers with Thomas Kennedy (left), Secretary-Treasurer of the UMW, and Pery Tetlow (center), president of UMW District 17, at the War Labor Board conference 15 January 1943, about the anthracite coal miners' strike, 1943 January 15]]
;1943 (United States) :[[Fair Employment Practices Commission]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;1943 (United States) :[[Smith-Connolly Act]] passed by [[U.S. Congress]]. Act restricts the extent of political activities and strikes by unions during the duration of the war.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;1943 (United States) :[[1943 Bituminous Coal Strike|Bituminous Coal Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;1943 (United States) :[[Detroit, Michigan Hate Strike]] against [[African Americans]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;1943 (United States) :[[Detroit Race Riot (1943)|Detroit Race Riots]] against African Americans occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;1944 (United States) :[[Philadelphia transit strike of 1944|Philadelphia Transit Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p027" />
;28 December 1944 (United States) :President Franklin D. Roosevelt ordered the Army to seize the executive offices of [[Montgomery Ward|Montgomery Ward and Company]] after the corporation failed to comply with a [[National War Labor Board (1942–1945)|National War Labor Board]] directive regarding union shops.
;1945 (INTERNATIONAL) :[[International Federation of Trade Unions]] becomes the [[World Federation of Trade Unions]]
;1945 (United States) :[[Kelsey-Hayes Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xxviii}}</ref>
;1945 (United States) :[[New York City Longshoremen's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1945 (United States) :[[Montgomery Ward Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1945 (United States) :[[Oil Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1946 (United States) :Workers in packinghouses nation-wide went on strike.
[[File:Doctor's office. The doctor for this camp is hired by Dr. Anderson, head doctor for the Kingston Pocahontas Coal... - NARA - 540721.jpg|thumb|alt=Doctor's office for the Kingston Pocahontas Coal Company, 1946|Doctor's office. The doctor for this camp is hired by Dr. Anderson, head doctor for the Kingston Pocahontas Coal Company, locally. Since the strike Dr. Anderson has cut off all funds for cleaning of this office. Kingston Pocahontas Coal Company, Exeter Mine, Welch, McDowell County, West Virginia, 10 August 1946]]
;1946 (United States) :[[Bituminous Coal Strike of 1946]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1946 (United States) :[[Electrical Manufacturing Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1946 (United States) :[[General Motors Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1946 (United States) :[[Pittsburgh Power Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1946 (United States) :[[Railroad Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1946 (United States) :[[Steel Strike of 1946]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1 April 1946 (United States) :A strike by 400,000 mine workers in the U.S. began. U.S. troops seized railroads and coal mines the following month.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;4 October 1946 (United States) :The U.S. Navy seized oil refineries in order to break a 20-state post-war strike.
;1947 (United States) :[[Taft–Hartley Act]] passed by U.S. Congress. The Act restricted union practices and permitted states to ban union security agreements.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1947 (United States) :[[R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1947 (United States) :[[Telephone Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;20 June 1947 (United States) :The [[Taft–Hartley Labor Act]], curbing strikes, was vetoed by President Truman. Congress overrode the veto.
;1948 (United States) :[[Progressive Party (United States, 1948)|Progressive Party]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;20 April 1948 (United States) :Labor leader [[Walter Reuther]] was shot and seriously wounded by would-be assassins.
;1949 (INTERNATIONAL) :[[International Confederation of Free Trade Unions]] splits from the [[World Federation of Trade Unions]]
;1949 (United States) :[[Congress of Industrial Organizations]] expelled two unions for alleged communist influence.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1949 (United States) :[[Hawaii Dock Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
===1950s=== ;1950 (United States) :[[Congress of Industrial Organizations]] expelled nine unions for alleged communist influence.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1950 (United States) :[[United Auto Workers]] and [[General Motors]] reached agreement on a contract that provided pensions and wage increases over the duration of the signed contract.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1950 (United States) :[[Western Federation of Miners#Salt of the Earth|''Salt of the Earth'' Strike of New Mexico]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1950 (International) :The [[Freedom of Association and Protection of the Right to Organise Convention, 1948]], one of the two primary labor conventions of the [[International Labour Organization|ILO]], came into force on 4 July.
;27 August 1950 (United States) :President Truman ordered the U.S. Army to seize all the nation's railroads to prevent a general strike. The railroads were not returned to their owners until two years later.
;1951 (International) :The [[Right to Organise and Collective Bargaining Convention, 1949]], one of the two primary labor conventions of the [[International Labour Organization|ILO]], came into force on 18 July.
;1952 (United States) :[[George Meany]] is elected president of the [[American Federation of Labor]].<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
[[File:Photograph of President Truman in the Oval Office, conferring with labor leader Walter Reuther, president of the... - NARA - 200406.jpg|thumb|alt=President Truman in Oval Office with labor leader Walter Reuther|Photograph of President Truman in the Oval Office, conferring with labor leader Walter Reuther, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, 1952 December 12.]]
;1952 (United States) :[[Walter Reuther]] is elected president of the [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]].<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1952 (United States) :[[Steel Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;8 April 1952 (United States) :President Truman ordered the U.S. Army to seize the nation's steel mills to avert a strike. The act was ruled to be illegal by the Supreme Court on 2 June.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1953 (United States) :[[American Federation of Labor]] and the [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]] reached an agreement to not raid from each other's membership.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1953 (United States) :[[American Federation of Labor]] expelled the [[International Longshoremen's Union]] on grounds of corruption.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1953 (United States) :[[Louisiana Sugar Cane Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1954 (United States) :[[Kohler Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1955 (United States) :[[United Auto Workers]] successfully negotiate with [[Ford Motor Company]] for supplementary unemployment benefits.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1955 (United States) :[[Southern Telephone Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;April 1955 (United States) :Textile workers strike of 1955, in both [[New Bedford, Massachusetts|New Bedford]] and [[Fall River, Massachusetts|Fall River]], [[Massachusetts]]. Strike over a nickel raise was led and negotiated by Union President Manuel "Manny" Fernandes Jr., who resolved the strike and got the workers a nickel raise.
;5 December 1955 (United States) :The two largest labor organizations in the U.S. merged to form the [[AFL-CIO]], with a membership estimated at 15 million. [[George Meany]] served as the first president of the combined organization.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1956 (United States) :[[East Coast Longshoremen's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1956 (United States) :[[Steel Strike of 1956]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;April 1956 (Canada) :The largest Canadian trade union center, the [[Canadian Labour Congress]] (CLC), was formed.
;5 April 1956 (United States) :Columnist [[Victor Riesel]], a crusader against labor racketeers, was blinded in New York City when a hired assailant threw sulfuric acid in his face.
;1957 (United States) :[[AFL–CIO|American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations]] expelled [[International Brotherhood Of Teamsters#The influence of organized crime|International Brotherhood of Teamsters]], Bakery Workers, and Laundry Workers on the grounds of corruption.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1959 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] passed the [[Labor Management Reporting and Disclosure Act]].<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;1959 (United States) :[[Steel strike of 1959]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;14 September 1959 (United States) :The [[Landrum–Griffin Act]] passes, restricting union activity.<ref name="fillippelli_p028" />
;7 November 1959 (United States) :The [[Taft–Hartley Act]] is invoked by the Supreme Court to break a steel strike.
===1960s=== ;1960 (United States) :[[Negro American Labor Council]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p029">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xxix}}</ref>
;1960 (United States) :[[General Electric Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1960 (United States) :[[Seamen's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1962 (United States) :President John F Kennedy issues [[Executive Order 10988]] establishing limited collective bargaining rights for federal employees and widely regarded as the impetus for the expansion of public sector bargaining rights at state and local levels in the years to come.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1962 (United States) :[[1962 New York City newspaper strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1962 (United States) :[[East Coast Longshoremen's Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1 April 1963 (United States) :The [[1962 New York City newspaper strike]], longest newspaper strike in U.S. history ended. The 9 major newspapers in New York City had ceased publication over 114 days before.
;10 June 1963 (United States) :Congress passed the [[Equal Pay Act of 1963|Equal Pay Act]] mandating equal pay to women.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1965 (United States) :[[United Farm Workers Organizing Committee]] founded.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1965 (United States) :[[Delano grape strike|California Grape Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1966 (United States) :[[New York Transportation Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1967 (United States) :[[Copper Strike]] started.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1968 (United States) :Members of four railroad unions voted overwhelmingly for the largest union merger ever in the railroad industry. The merger created a powerful new union called the [[United Transportation Union]] (UTU).
;1968 (United States) :[[New York City teachers' strike of 1968|New York City Teachers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;[[May 1968 in France|May 1968]] (France) :What began as a student protest developed into a nationwide [[general strike]].
;1968 (INTERNATIONAL) :The IFCTU becomes the [[World Confederation of Labour]]
[[File:President Nixon with AFL-CIO President George Meaney and Secretary of Labor George Schultz - NARA - 194613.tif|thumb|President Nixon with AFL-CIO President George Meaney and Secretary of Labor George Schultz - NARA - 194613]]
;1969 (United States) :[[1969 Charleston hospital strike#Charleston hospital strike|Charleston, South Carolina, Hospital Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
===1970s=== ;1970 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] enacted [[Occupational Safety and Health Act]].<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1970 (United States) :[[General Motors Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1970 (United States) :[[Postal Workers Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;5 January 1970 (United States) :[[Joseph Yablonski]], unsuccessful reform candidate to unseat [[W. A. Boyle]] as President of the [[United Mine Workers]], was murdered, along with his wife and daughter, in their [[Clarksville, Pennsylvania]] home by assassins acting on Boyle's orders. Boyle was later convicted of the killing.
:[[West Virginia]] miners went on strike the following day in protest.
;18 March 1970 (United States) :The first mass work stoppage in the 195-year history of the United States Post Office Department began with a walkout of letter carriers in Brooklyn and Manhattan,<ref name="fillippelli_p029" /> soon involving 210,000 of the nation's 750,000 postal employees. With mail service virtually paralyzed in New York, Detroit, and Philadelphia, President Nixon declared a state of national emergency and assigned military units to New York City post offices. The stand-off culminated two weeks later.
[[File:Cesar chavez crop2.jpg|[[César Chávez]], cofounder of UFW|thumb]]
;29 July 1970 (United States) :[[United Farm Workers]] forced California grape growers to sign an agreement after a five-year strike.
;1971 (United States) :[[New York City Police Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1972 (United States) :[[Farah Clothing Workers' Strike and Boycott]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1972 (United States) :[[Lordstown, Ohio, Auto Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1972 (United States) :[[Philadelphia Teachers Strike]] started.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1974 (United States) :[[Coalition of Labor Union Women]] formed.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1974 (United States) :[[Employment Retirement Income Security Act]] passed by [[U.S. Congress]].<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1974 (United States) :[[Baltimore Police Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1975 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] voted down union-sponsored bill to reform the basic United States labor laws.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
[[File:The Washington Star Building (2893479361).jpg|thumb|alt=The Washington Star Building (2893479361)|On 1 October 1975, press operators at the Post went on strike, severely damaging all printing presses before leaving the building]]
;1 October 1975 (United States) :[[Washington Post Pressmen's Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1976 (United States) :[[U.S. Congress]] voted down union-sponsored bill to make it easier for construction unions to organize.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1977 (United States) :[[Bituminous Coal Strike of 1977-1978]] started.<ref name="fillippelli_p029" />
;1977 (United States) :[[Coors Brewing Company#Labor issues|Coors Beer Strike and Boycott]] started.<ref name="fillippelli_p030">{{cite book |last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|title=Labor conflict in the United States : an encyclopedia|year=1990|publisher=Garland Publishing Co.|location=New York|isbn=082407968X|pages=xxx}}</ref>
;1977 (United States) :[[J.P. Stevens Boycott]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1977 (United States) :[[Willmar, Minnesota, Bank Workers' Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1978 (United States) :[[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania Newspaper Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
[[File:Lkirkland.jpg|thumb|Portrait of Lane Kirkland by [[Richard Whitney (artist)|Richard Whitney]]]]
;1979 (United States) :[[Lane Kirkland]] elected president of the [[AFL-CIO]].<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1979 (United States) :[[Independent Trucker Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1979 (United States) :The film [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/norma_rae/ Norma Rae], based on a real life character trying to unionize a textile mill, is released. It wins an Academy Award for best actress.
===1980s=== ;September 1980 (Poland) :The trade union [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]] (''Solidarność'') is established at the [[Gdańsk Shipyard]], and originally led by Nobel Peace Prize winner [[Lech Wałęsa]]. Within the year the government implements [[Martial law in Poland|martial law]] in an attempt to quell nationwide civil unrest and protest.
;1980 (United States) :[[Joyce Miller]] joined the [[AFL–CIO]] executive board as the first female board member.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
[[File:Reagan speaks on air traffic controllers strike 1981.jpg|thumb|Reagan speaks on air traffic controllers strike 1981]]
;3 August 1981 (United States) :Federal air traffic controllers began a [[Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization (1968)#August 1981 strike|nationwide strike]] after their union rejected the government's final offer for a new contract. Most of the 13,000 striking controllers defied the back-to-work order, and were dismissed by President Reagan on 5 August.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" /> Reagan ordered them to leave.
:Largest labor rally in United States history broke out in protest of Reagan's order.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1982 (United States) :[[Baseball Players' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;October 1982 (United States) :A boycott was initiated by the [[International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers|International Association of Machinists]] (IAM) against [[Brown & Sharpe]]. The [[National Labor Relations Board]] later charged Brown & Sharpe with regressive bargaining, and of entering into negotiations with the express purpose of not reaching an agreement with the union. ''(See [[International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers|IAM]] for more details.)''.
;1983 (United States) :[[Phelps-Dodge Copper Strike]] commenced.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1984 (United States) :[[Yale University Clerical Workers' Strike]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1985 (United States) :[[Hormel Meatpackers' Strike]] occurred but ultimately failed.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1985 (United States) :[[Los Angeles County Sanitation Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1985 (United States) :[[Yale University Clerical Workers' Strike]] ended.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1985 ([[Vatican City]]) :The [[Association of Vatican Lay Workers]] was formed, but was not recognized by the Vatican authorities until 1993. It is the sole trade union in [[Vatican City]] and represents the majority of the 3000 employees who work in the city state.
;1986 (United States) :[[Trans World Airlines Flight Attendants' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1986 (United States) :[[United States Steel#Labor|USX (United States Steel) Lockout]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;6 October 1986 (United States) :Female flight attendants won an 18-year lawsuit against [[United Airlines]], which had fired them for getting married. The lawsuit was resolved when a U.S. district court approved the reinstatement of 475 attendants and $37 million back-pay settlement for 1,725 flight attendants. (United Airlines, Inc. v. McDonald, 432 U.S. 385 (1977))<ref>[http://www.feminist.org/research/chronicles/fc1986.html] [http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?court=us&vol=432&invol=385]</ref>
;1987 (United States) :[[Paperworkers' Strike and Lockout]] began.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1987 (United States) :[[Professional Football Players' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1989 (United States) :[[Eastern Airlines Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;1989 (United States) :[[Pittston Coal strike|Pittston Coal Company Mine Workers' Strike]] occurred.<ref name="fillippelli_p030" />
;4 April 1989 (Poland) :Round table negotiations between [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]] and the then-Communist government result in semi-free parliamentary elections in Poland, a pivotal moment in [[revolutions of 1989|fall of the Iron Curtain]] in Eastern Europe. [[Solidarity (Polish trade union)|Solidarity]] leader [[Lech Wałęsa]] is elected President in August of that year.<ref>{{cite web|last=Kennedy|first=Michael D.|title=Negotiating revolution in Poland|url=http://www.ucis.pitt.edu/nceeer/2002-815-10g-Kennedy.pdf|work=NCEEER|year=2002|accessdate=14 July 2013}}</ref>
==2000–99==
===2000s===
;14 January 2003 (United States) :20,000 employees at 48 plants in 33 states struck against [[General Electric]], the first strike against GE in 33 years, over a plan to shift more health care costs to employees and retirees.<ref>{{cite web |title=Today in labor history: 20,000 GE workers strike over health care |url=http://peoplesworld.org/today-in-labor-history-20-000-ge-workers-strike-over-health-care/ |accessdate=2015-10-30}}</ref>
;2006 (INTERNATIONAL) :The [[World Confederation of Labour]] merges with the [[International Confederation of Free Trade Unions]] and eight other trade union affiliations to found the [[International Trade Union Confederation]].<ref name=ilo_lauds_ituc>{{cite web |title=ILO Director-General lauds formation of new global union federation |work=ILO Online press room |url=http://www.ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/media-centre/press-releases/WCMS_077094/lang--en/index.htm |accessdate=2006-11-03}}</ref>
===2010s===
19 September 2012 ([[Texas]]) : Coke workers of the Fossil Creek Facility (in Fort Worth) vote 215 to 191 to not be represented by The [[International Brotherhood of Teamsters]].<ref name=coca_cola_star_telegram>{{cite news|last=Schlacter|first=Barry|title=Workers vote against joining union at Coca-Cola in Fort Worth|url=http://www.star-telegram.com/2012/09/20/4274510/workers-vote-against-joining-union.html#storylink=cpy|accessdate=18 December 2013|newspaper=Star-Telegram|date=20 September 2012}}</ref>

[[File:US Adult Incarceration Rate by State.svg|thumb|400px|A map of [[List of U.S. states by incarceration rate|U.S. states by adult incarceration rate]] per 100,000 adult population. State prisons and local jails. Excludes federal prisoners.]]
In October 2013, the incarceration rate of the United States of America was the highest in the world, at 716 per 100,000 of the national population. While the United States represents about 4.4 percent of the world's population, it houses around 22 percent of the world's prisoners.<ref>Roy Walmsley (November 21, 2013). [http://www.prisonstudies.org/sites/default/files/resources/downloads/wppl_10.pdf World Prison Population List (tenth edition)]. ''[[International Centre for Prison Studies]].'' Retrieved July 11, 2014.</ref> Corrections (which includes prisons, jails, probation, and parole) cost around $74 billion in 2007 according to the [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]].<ref name=bjscosts>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120101181331/http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/glance/tables/exptyptab.cfm Direct expenditures by justice function, 1982-2007 (billions of dollars)]. Inflation adjusted to 2007 dollars. [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]] (BJS). Retrieved 1 Jan 2012 by the [[Internet Archive]]. See [https://web.archive.org/web/20120101082347/http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/glance/exptyp.cfm BJS timeline graph based on the data].</ref><ref name=bjscosts2>[http://www.bjs.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=2192 Justice Expenditures and Employment, FY 1982-2007 - Statistical Tables] (NCJ 236218). Published December 2011. [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]] (BJS). By Tracey Kyckelhahn, Ph.D., BJS statistician. See table 2 of the [http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/jee8207st.pdf PDF]. "Total justice expenditures, by justice function, FY 1982–2007 (real dollars)". A total of around $74 billion for corrections in 2007.</ref>
In 2016, the [[Prison Policy Initiative]] estimated that in the United States, about 2,298,300 people were incarcerated out of a population of 323.1 million. This means that 0.71% of the population was behind bars. Of those who were incarcerated, about 1,351,000 people were in state prison, 646,000 in local jails, 211,000 in federal prisons, 34,000 in youth correctional facilities, 33,000 in immigration detention camps, 14,000 in territorial prisons, 5,500 in civil commitment, 2,400 in Indian country jails, and 1,400 in United States military prisons.<ref>[https://www.prisonpolicy.org/reports/pie2016.html Mass Incarceration: The Whole Pie 2016 ]</ref>
== Prison and jail population == {{See also|List of U.S. states by incarceration rate}} [[File:US incarceration timeline-clean.svg|thumb|350px|Total incarceration in the United States by year]] [[File:US adult correctional population timeline.gif|thumb|350px|Total US incarceration peaked in 2008. Total correctional population peaked in 2007.<ref name=cpus2013/>]] Total U.S. incarceration (prisons and jails) peaked in 2008. Total correctional population peaked in 2007.<ref name=cpus2013>[http://www.bjs.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=5177 Correctional Populations in the United States, 2013] (NCJ 248479). Published December 2014 by [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]] (BJS). By Lauren E. Glaze and Danielle Kaeble, BJS statisticians. See appendix table 5 on page 13 in the [http://www.bjs.gov/content/pub/pdf/cpus13.pdf PDF], for "Estimated number of persons supervised by adult correctional systems, by correctional status, 2000–2013."</ref> If all prisoners are counted (including those juvenile, territorial, [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement]] (ICE) ([[Immigration detention in the United States|immigration detention]]), Indian country, and military), then in 2008 the United States had around 24.7% of the world's 9.8 million prisoners.<ref name=prisoners2008>''[http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=1763 Prisoners in 2008] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716170211/http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=1763 |date=2011-07-16 }}.'' (NCJ 228417). December 2009 report from the [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]]. By William J. Sabol, Ph.D. and Heather C. West, Ph.D., BJS Statisticians. Also, Matthew Cooper, BJS Intern. === Growth === [[File:U.S. incarceration rates 1925 onwards.png|thumb|350px|A graph of the incarceration rate under state and federal jurisdiction per 100,000 population 1925–2008. (Omits local jail inmates. Top line = males. Bottom line = females. Middle line = combined.)]] In the last forty years, incarceration has increased with rates upwards of 500% despite crime rates decreasing nationally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sentencingproject.org/issues/incarceration/|title=Incarceration {{!}} The Sentencing Project|website=The Sentencing Project|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> Between the years 2001 and 2012, crime rates (both property and violent crimes) have consistently declined at a rate of 22% after already falling an additional 30% in years prior between 1991 and 2001.<ref name="brookings.edu">{{Cite news|url=https://www.brookings.edu/research/ten-economic-facts-about-crime-and-incarceration-in-the-united-states/|title=Ten Economic Facts about Crime and Incarceration in the United States {{!}} Brookings Institution|date=2014-05-01|newspaper=Brookings|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> As of 2012, there are 710 people per every 100,000 U.S. residents in the United States that are imprisoned in either local jails, state prisons, federal prisons, and privately operated facilities.<ref name="brookings.edu"/> This correlates to incarcerating a number close to almost a quarter of the prison population in the entire world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://scholarworks.sjsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1037&context=themis|title=Themis: Research Journal of Justice Studies and Forensic Science|last=Hanna|first=Peter|date=2016-05-10|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> Mass incarceration is an intervening variable to more incarceration.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://qz.com/458675/in-america-mass-incarceration-has-caused-more-crime-than-its-prevented/|title=In America, mass incarceration has caused more crime than it's prevented|last=Schrager|first=Allison|newspaper=Quartz|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>
The [[Bureau of Justice Statistics]] has released a study which finds that, despite the total number of prisoners incarcerated for drug-related offenses increasing by 57,000 between 1997 and 2004, the proportion of drug offenders to total prisoners in State prison populations stayed steady at 21%. The percentage of Federal prisoners serving time for drug offenses declined from 63% in 1997 to 55% in that same period.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090830192737/http://www.ojp.usdoj.gov/bjs/pub/pdf/dudsfp04.pdf Christopher J. Mumola: Drug Use and Dependence, State and Federal Prisoners, 2004, U.S. Department of Justice, October 2006, NCJ 213530]</ref> In the twenty-five years since the passage of the [[Anti-Drug Abuse Act]] of 1986, the United States penal population rose from around 300,000 to more than two million.<ref>{{cite book|last=Alexander|first=Michelle|title=The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness|year=2010|publisher=The New Press|location=New York|page=6|title-link=The New Jim Crow}}</ref> Between 1986 and 1991, African-American women's incarceration in state prisons for drug offenses increased by 828 percent.<ref>{{cite book|last=Golden|first=Renny|title=War on the Family: Mothers in Prison and the Families They Leave Behind|year=2005|publisher=Taylor and Friends|location=New York|page=46}}</ref>
In 2009, the [[U.S. Department of Justice]] announced that the growth rate of the state prison population had fallen to its lowest since 2006, but it still had a 0.2% growth-rate compared to the total U.S. prison population.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/pub/pdf/py09ac.pdf |title=US DOJ Data Brief: Prisoners at Yearend 2009–Advance Counts}}</ref> The [[Prisons in California|California state prison system]] population fell in 2009, the first year that populations had fallen in 38 years.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.aolnews.com/nation/article/us-state-prison-population-falls-for-first-time-in-38-years/19403469 |title=US State Prison Population Falls for First Time in 38 Years |last=Martelle |first=Scott |year=2010 |publisher=AOL |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322200340/http://www.aolnews.com/nation/article/us-state-prison-population-falls-for-first-time-in-38-years/19403469 |archivedate=2010-03-22 |df= }}</ref>
When looking at specific populations within the criminal justice system the growth rates are vastly different. In 1977, there were just slightly more than eleven thousand incarcerated women. By 2004, the number of [[Incarceration of women in the United States|women under state or federal prison]] had increased by 757 percent, to more than 111,000, and the percentage of women in prison has increased every year, at roughly double the rate of men, since 2000.<ref>{{cite book|last=Talvi|first=Silja J.A|title=Women Behind Bars: The Crisis of Women in the U.S Prison System|year=2007|publisher=Seal Press|location=California|page=3}}</ref> The rate of incarcerated women has expanded at about 4.6% annually between 1995 and 2005 with women now accounting for 7% of the population in state and federal prisons.

Percent of adult males incarcerated by race and ethnicity.svg|thumb|400px|2009. Percent of adult males incarcerated by race and ethnicity.<ref>[http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=1006 Prison Inmates at Midyear 2009 - Statistical Tables] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130303174105/http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/index.cfm?ty=pbdetail&iid=1006 |date=2013-03-03 }} (NCJ 230113). [[U.S. Bureau of Justice Statistics]]. The rates are for adult males, and are from Tables 18 and 19 of the [http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/pub/pdf/pjim06.pdf PDF file] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111027141258/http://bjs.ojp.usdoj.gov/content/pub/pdf/pjim06.pdf |date=2011-10-27 }}. Rates per 100,000 were converted to percentages.</ref>]] A 2014 report by the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] identified two main causes of the increase in the United States' incarceration rate over the previous 40 years: longer prison sentences and increases in the likelihood of imprisonment. The same report found that longer prison sentences were the main driver of increasing incarceration rates since 1990.<ref>{{cite book | url=http://www.nap.edu/read/18613/chapter/5 | title=The Growth of Incarceration in the United States: Exploring Causes and Consequences | publisher=National Research Council| author=Travis, Jeremy | year=2014 | pages=40}}</ref>
=== Increased sentencing laws === {{Further|Three-strikes law}}
Even though there are other countries that commit more inmates to prison annually, the fact that the United States keeps their prisoners longer causes the total rate to become higher. To give an example, the average burglary sentence in the United States is 16 months, compared to 5 months in [[Canada]] and 7 months in England.<ref name=liptak>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/23/us/23prison.html?pagewanted=print | work=The New York Times | title=Inmate Count in U.S. Dwarfs Other Nations' | first=Adam | last=Liptak | date=2008-04-23 | accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref>
Looking at reasons for imprisonment will further clarify why the incarceration rate and length of sentences are so high. The practice of imposing longer prison sentences on repeat offenders is common in many countries but the [[three-strikes law]]s in the U.S. with mandatory 25 year imprisonment — implemented in many states in the 1990s — are statutes enacted by state governments in the United States which mandate state courts to impose harsher sentences on habitual offenders who are previously convicted of two prior serious criminal offenses and then commit a third.
=== Economic and age contributions === Crime rates in low-income areas are much higher than in middle to high class areas. As a result, Incarceration rates in low-income areas are much higher than in wealthier areas due to these high crime rates.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hamiltonproject.org/papers/ten_economic_facts_about_crime_and_incarceration_in_the_united_states|title=Ten Economic Facts about Crime and Incarceration in the United States {{!}} The Hamilton Project|website=www.hamiltonproject.org|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> When the incarcerated or criminal is a youth, there is a significant impact on the individual and rippling effects on entire communities. Social capital is lost when an individual is incarcerated. How much social capital is lost is hard to accurately estimate, however Aizer and Doyle found a strong positive correlation between lower income as an adult if an individual is incarcerated in their youth in comparison to those who are not incarcerated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Aizer|first=Anna|last2=Doyle|first2=Joseph J.|date=2015-02-02|title=Juvenile Incarceration, Human Capital, and Future Crime: Evidence from Randomly Assigned Judges*|url=http://qje.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2015/04/11/qje.qjv003|journal=The Quarterly Journal of Economics|volume=130|issue=2|language=en|pages=759–803|doi=10.1093/qje/qjv003|issn=0033-5533|hdl=1721.1/97380}}</ref> 63 percent to 66 percent of those involved in crimes are under the age of thirty.<ref name=":0" /> People incarcerated at a younger age lose the capability to invest in themselves and in their communities. Their children and families become susceptible to financial burden preventing them from escaping low-income communities. This contributes to the recurring cycle of poverty that is positively correlated with incarceration.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mosley|first=Paul|last2=Verschoor|first2=Arjan|date=2005-03-01|title=Risk Attitudes and the 'Vicious Circle of Poverty'|journal=The European Journal of Development Research|volume=17|issue=1|pages=59–88|doi=10.1080/09578810500066548|issn=0957-8811}}</ref> Poverty rates have not been curbed despite steady economic growth. Poverty is not the sole dependent variable for increasing incarceration rates. Incarceration leads to more incarceration by putting families and communities at a dynamic social disadvantage.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Cj7RCwAAQBAJ&pg=PR17&dq=mass+incarceration+leads+to+more+incarceration#v=onepage&q=mass%20incarceration%20leads%20to%20more%20incarceration&f=false|title=Imprisoning Communities: How Mass Incarceration Makes Disadvantaged Neighborhoods Worse|last=Clear|first=Todd R.|date=2009-03-27|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199728237|language=en}}</ref>
=== Drug sentencing laws === The "[[War on Drugs]]" is a policy that was initiated by [[Richard Nixon]] with the [[Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970]] and vigorously pursued by [[Ronald Reagan]].<ref name=JC>{{cite book|last=Alexander|first=Michelle|title=The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindess|year=2010|publisher=The New Press|location=New York|page=52}}</ref> By 2010, drug offenders in federal prison had increased to 500,000 per year, up from 41,000 in 1985. According to [[Michelle Alexander]], drug related charges accounted for more than half the rise in state prisoners between 1985 and 2000. 31 million people have been arrested on drug related charges, approximately 1 in 10 Americans.<ref>{{cite book|last=Alexander|first=Michelle|title=The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness|year=2010|publisher=The New Press|location=New York|page=60}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Shackles Beyond the Sentence: How Legal Financial Obligations Create a Permanent Underclass|ssrn = 2628977|publisher = Social Science Research Network|date = 2015-07-09|location = Rochester, NY|last = SpearIt}}</ref> In contrast, John Pfaff of [[Fordham Law School]] has accused Alexander of exaggerating the influence of the War on Drugs on the rise in the United States' incarceration rate: according to him, the percent of state prisoners whose primary offense was drug-related peaked at 22% in 1990.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/crime/2015/02/mass_incarceration_a_provocative_new_theory_for_why_so_many_americans_are.html | title=Why Are So Many Americans in Prison? | work=Slate | date=6 February 2015 | accessdate=14 February 2016 | author=Neyfakh, Leon}}</ref> The Brookings Institution reconciles the differences between Alexander and Pfaff by explaining two ways to look at the prison population as it relates to drug crimes, concluding "The picture is clear: Drug crimes have been the predominant reason for new admissions into state and federal prisons in recent decades" and "rolling back the war on drugs would not, as Pfaff and Urban Institute scholars maintain, totally solve the problem of mass incarceration, but it could help a great deal, by reducing exposure to prison." <ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.brookings.edu/blog/social-mobility-memos/2015/11/25/drug-offenders-in-american-prisons-the-critical-distinction-between-stock-and-flow/ | title=Drug offenders in American prisons: The critical distinction between stock and flow | work=Brookings | date=25 November 2015 | accessdate=1 September 2016 | author=Rothwell, Jonathan}}</ref>
After the passage of Reagan's [[Anti-Drug Abuse Act]] in 1986, incarceration for non-violent offenses dramatically increased. The Act imposed the same five-year mandatory sentence on those with convictions involving crack as on those possessing 100 times as much powder cocaine.<ref name=JC /><ref name="Lyons">{{cite web|last=Lyons|first=John|title=War on the Family: Mothers in Prison and the Children They Leave Behind|work=DVD|publisher=Peace Productions}}</ref> This had a disproportionate effect on low-level street dealers and users of crack, who were more commonly poor blacks, Latinos, the young, and women.<ref>{{cite book|last=Golden|first=Renny|title=War on the Family: Mothers in Prison and the Families They Leave Behind|year=2005|publisher=Routledge|location=New York|page=45}}</ref>
Courts were given more discretion in sentencing by the ''[[Kimbrough v. United States]]'' (2007) decision, and the disparity was decreased to 18:1 by the [[Fair Sentencing Act of 2010]].<ref name=famm>[http://www.famm.org/FederalSentencing/USCongress/BillsinCongress/TheFairSentencingActof2010.aspx "Fair Sentencing Act of 2010"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303203132/http://www.famm.org/FederalSentencing/USCongress/BillsinCongress/TheFairSentencingActof2010.aspx |date=March 3, 2012 }}, Families Against Mandatory Minimums, famm.org. Retrieved September 30, 2010.</ref> {{As of|2006}}, 49.3% of state prisoners, or 656,000 individuals, were incarcerated for non-[[violent crime]]s. {{As of|2008}}, 90.7% of federal prisoners, or 165,457 individuals, were incarcerated for non-violent offenses.<ref name=prisoners2008/>
By 2003, 58% of all women in federal prison were convicted of drug offenses.<ref>[[Bureau of Justice Statistics]]. Sourcebook of Criminal Justice Statistics Online (30th ed.). 2002. ''Cited in'' [https://www.aclu.org/womens-rights/words-prison-did-you-know#_edn13 "Words From Prison - Did You Know...?"], [[American Civil Liberties Union]], June 12, 2006.</ref> Black and Hispanic women in particular have been disproportionately affected by the War on Drugs. Since 1986, incarceration rates have risen by 400% for women of all races, while rates for Black women have risen by 800%.<ref>Marc Mauer, Cathy Potler & Richard Wolf, Gender and Justice: Women, Drugs, and Sentencing Policy, [[The Sentencing Project]]. November 1997. ''Cited in'' [https://www.aclu.org/womens-rights/words-prison-did-you-know#_edn13 "Words From Prison - Did You Know...?"], [[American Civil Liberties Union]], June 12, 2006 and {{cite web|title=Caught in the Net: Impact of Drug Policies on Women and Families|url=https://www.aclu.org/files/images/asset_upload_file431_23513.pdf|publisher=American Civil Liberties Union|accessdate=15 April 2011}}</ref> Formerly incarcerated Black women are also most negatively impacted by the collateral legal consequences of conviction.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The Modern Day Scarlet Letter|ssrn = 2460898|date = 2015|location = 83 Fordham L. Rev. 2999 (2015)|first = Ifeoma|last = Ajunwa}}</ref>
According to the [[American Civil Liberties Union]], "Even when women have minimal or no involvement in the drug trade, they are increasingly caught in the ever-widening net cast by current drug laws, through provisions of the criminal law such as those involving [[Conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]], [[accomplice liability]], and [[constructive possession]] that expand [[criminal liability]] to reach partners, relatives and bystanders."<ref>"[https://www.aclu.org/womens-rights/words-prison-did-you-know#_edn13 Words From Prison - Did You Know...?]", [[American Civil Liberties Union]], June 12, 2006.</ref>
These new policies also disproportionately affect African-American women. According to [[Dorothy E. Roberts]], the explanation is that poor women, who are disproportionately black, are more likely to be placed under constant supervision by the State in order to receive social services.<ref>{{cite book|last=Roberts|first=Dorothy|title=Killing the Black Body: Race, Reproduction, and the Meaning of Liberty|year=1997|publisher=Vintage Books|location=New York|page=172}}</ref> They are then more likely to be caught by officials who are instructed to look specifically for drug offenses. Roberts argues that the criminal justice system's creation of new crimes has a direct effect on the number of women, especially black women, who then become incarcerated.
===Racialization ===
One of the first laws in the U.S. against drugs was the Opium Exclusion Act of 1909. It prohibited the smoking of opium, which was ingested but not smoked by a substantial portion of caucasian housewives in America. It was smoked mainly by Asian American immigrants coming to build the railroads. These immigrants were targeted with anti-Asian sentiment, as many voters believed they were losing jobs to Asian immigrants.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
This pattern was repeated in the late twentieth century with higher penalties for crack cocaine than powder. Crack was consumed primarily by African Americans, while powder was consumed more by the white middle-class. The substantial penalties for crack contributed to the five-fold increase in incarcerations seen in the plot above.{{Citation needed|reason=I'm sure that the difference in penalties between crack and powder have been discussed. I remember seeing a movie about the 2008 global financial crisis that claimed that Wall Street in the "cocaine consumption capital of the world." References on this should be available and should be cited here.|date=May 2017}} For instance, the disproportionate number of African Americans compared to other racial groups in the United States that are arrested or incarcerated. Figures from 2008 offer a better illustration of the situation with 28% of arrests involving African Americans and African American men comprising almost half of the current incarcerated population in the United States.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Warde|first1=Bryan|title=Black Male Disproportionality in the Criminal Justice Systems of the USA, Canada, and England: a Comparative Analysis of Incarceration|journal=Journal of African American Studies|date=December 2013|volume=17|issue=4|page=461|url=https://www.jstor.org.proxy-um.researchport.umd.edu/stable/43525522|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref>
===Prison privatization=== In the 1980s, the rising number of people incarcerated as a result of the War on Drugs and the wave of privatization that occurred under the [[Reagan Administration]] saw the emergence of the for-profit prison industry. Prior to the 1980s, [[private prison]]s did not exist in the US.<ref>Khalek, Rania. [http://www.salon.com/2011/12/01/how_private_prisons_game_the_system/ How private prisons game the system]. Salon.com. Dec 1, 2011.</ref><ref>[[Bernard Harcourt|Harcourt, Bernard]] (2012). ''[http://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674066168 The Illusion of Free Markets: Punishment and the Myth of Natural Order].'' [[Harvard University Press]]. {{ISBN|0674066162}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=LW8I66EGmfcC&lpg=PP1&vq=GEO%20Group&pg=PA235#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 235]</ref><ref>Selman, Donna and Paul Leighton (2010). ''[https://rowman.com/ISBN/9781442201729/Punishment-for-Sale-Private-Prisons-Big-Business-and-the-Incarceration-Binge Punishment for Sale: Private Prisons, Big Business, and the Incarceration Binge].'' Rowman & Littlefield Publishers. {{ISBN|1442201738}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=5lBraTDtiSgC&lpg=PP1&pg=PR11#v=onepage&q&f=false p. xi]</ref>
In a 2011 report by the ACLU, it is claimed that the rise of the for-profit prison industry is a "major contributor" to "[[mass incarceration]]," along with bloated state budgets.<ref name="Shapiro">{{cite web|last=Shapiro|first=David|title=Banking on Bondage: Private Prisons and Mass Incarceration|url=https://www.aclu.org/files/assets/bankingonbondage_20111102.pdf|publisher=[[American Civil Liberties Union]]|accessdate=31 March 2013}}</ref> Louisiana, for example, has the highest rate of incarceration in the world with the majority of its prisoners being housed in privatized, for-profit facilities. Such institutions could face bankruptcy without a steady influx of prisoners.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chang|first=Cindy|title=Louisiana is the world's prison capital|url=http://www.nola.com/crime/index.ssf/2012/05/louisiana_is_the_worlds_prison.html|publisher=[[The Times-Picayune]]|date=29 May 2012|accessdate=4 April 2013}}</ref> A 2013 Bloomberg report states that in the past decade the number of inmates in for-profit prisons throughout the U.S. rose 44 percent.<ref>Margaret Newkirk & William Selway (12 July 2013). [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-07-12/gangs-ruled-prison-as-for-profit-model-put-blood-on-floor.html "Gangs Ruled Prison as For-Profit Model Put Blood on Floor."] [[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]. Retrieved 16 July 2013.</ref>
Corporations who operate prisons, such as the [[Corrections Corporation of America]] and The [[GEO Group]], spend significant amounts of money lobbying the federal government along with state governments.<ref name="Shapiro"/> The two aforementioned companies, the largest in the industry, have been contributors to the [[American Legislative Exchange Council]] (ALEC), which seeks to expand the privatization of corrections and lobbies for policies that would increase incarceration, such as three-strike laws and "truth-in-sentencing" legislation.<ref>Elk, Mike and Sloan, Bob (2011). [http://www.thenation.com/article/162478/hidden-history-alec-and-prison-labor The Hidden History of ALEC and Prison Labor]. ''[[The Nation]]''.</ref><ref>[http://www.sentencingproject.org/Admin/Documents/publications/inc_prisonprivatization.pdf Prison Privatization and the Use of Incarceration]. The Sentencing Project, September 2004. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070714063407/http://www.sentencingproject.org/Admin/Documents/publications/inc_prisonprivatization.pdf |date=July 14, 2007 }}</ref><ref name="Rutherford">{{cite news|url=https://www.rutherford.org/publications_resources/john_whiteheads_commentary/jailing_americans_for_profit_the_rise_of_the_prison_industrial_complex|title=Jailing Americans for Profit: The Rise of the Prison Industrial Complex|last=Whitehead|first=John|date=April 10, 2012|publisher=[[The Rutherford Institute]]|accessdate=April 2, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Sullivan, Laura">Sullivan, Laura (2010). [https://www.npr.org/2010/10/28/130833741/prison-economics-help-drive-ariz-immigration-law Prison Economics Help Drive Ariz. Immigration Law]. ''[[National Public Radio]]''.</ref><ref>Pat Beall (November 22, 2013). [http://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/news/big-business-group-behind-push-that-filled-florida/nbYTc/ Big business, legislators pushed for stiff sentences]. ''[[The Palm Beach Post]].'' Retrieved November 10, 2014.</ref><ref>Marie Gottschalk. ''[http://press.princeton.edu/titles/10731.html Caught: The Prison State and the Lockdown of American Politics].'' Princeton University Press, 2014. [https://books.google.com/books?id=iOs_BAAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA61#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 61]</ref> Prison companies also sign contracts with states that guarantee at least 90 percent of prison beds be filled. If these "lockup quotas" aren't met, the state must reimburse the prison company for the unused beds. Prison companies use the profits to expand and put pressure on lawmakers to incarcerate a certain number of people.<ref>Katy Hall and Jan Diehm (19 September 2013). [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/19/private-prisons_n_3955686.html One Disturbing Reason For Our Exploding Prison Population (INFOGRAPHIC)]. ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' Retrieved 20 September 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.inthepublicinterest.org/sites/default/files/Criminal%20Lockup%20Quota%20Report.pdf CRIMINAL: How Lockup Quotas and "Low-Crime Taxes" Guarantee Profits for Private Prison Corporations] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140424045843/http://www.inthepublicinterest.org/sites/default/files/Criminal%20Lockup%20Quota%20Report.pdf |date=2014-04-24 }}. ''In the Public Interest.'' Retrieved 20 September 2013.</ref> This influence on the government by the private prison industry has been referred to as the [[Prison–industrial complex]].<ref name="Rutherford"/>
The industry is well aware of what reduced crime rates could mean to their bottom line. This from the CCA's SEC report in 2010:
<blockquote>Our growth … depends on a number of factors we cannot control, including crime rates … [R]eductions in crime rates … could lead to reductions in arrests, convictions and sentences requiring incarceration at correctional facilities.<ref name="Shapiro"/></blockquote>
===Editorial policies of major media=== Gallup polling since 1989 has found that in most years in which there was a decline in the U.S. crime rate, a majority of Americans said that violent crime was getting worse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/150464/americans-believe-crime-worsening.aspx|title=Most Americans Believe Crime in U.S. Is Worsening|author=Gallup, Inc.|work=Gallup.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/179546/americans-crime-last-year.aspx|title=Most Americans Still See Crime Up Over Last Year|author=Gallup, Inc.|work=Gallup.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gallup.com/poll/165653/crime-americans-seem-noticed.aspx|title=U.S. Crime Is Up, but Americans Don't Seem to Have Noticed|author=Gallup, Inc.|work=Gallup.com}}</ref>
A substantial body of research claims that incarceration rates are primarily a function of media editorial policies, largely unrelated to the actual crime rate. ''Constructing Crime: Perspectives on Making News and Social Problems'' is a book collecting together papers on this theme.<ref>Potter and Kapeller (1998)</ref> The researchers say that the jump in incarceration rate from 0.1% to 0.5% of the United States population from 1975 to 2000 (documented in the figure above) was driven by changes in the editorial policies of the mainstream commercial media and is unrelated to any actual changes in crime. [[Media consolidation]] reduced competition on content. That allowed media company executives to maintain substantially the same audience while slashing budgets for investigative journalism and filling the space from the police blotter, which tended to increase and stabilize advertising revenue. It is safer, easier and cheaper to write about crimes committed by poor people than the wealthy. Poor people can be libeled with impunity, but major advertisers can materially impact the profitability of a commercial media organization by reducing their purchases of advertising space with that organization.
News media thrive on [[Media feeding frenzy|feeding frenzies]] (such as [[Missing white woman syndrome|missing white women]]) because they tend to reduce production costs while simultaneously building an audience interested in the latest development in a particular story. It takes a long time for a reporter to learn enough to write intelligently about a specific issue. Once a reporter has achieved that level of knowledge, it is easier to write subsequent stories. However, major advertisers have been known to spend their advertising budgets through different channels when they dislike the editorial policies. Therefore, a media feeding frenzy focusing on an issue of concern to an advertiser may reduce revenue and profits.<ref>McCheney (2004, p. 81) wrote, "A five-year study of investigative journalism on TV news completed in 2002 determined that investigative journalism has all but disappeared from the nation's commercial airwaves."</ref>
Sacco described how "competing news organizations responded to each other's coverage [while] the police, in their role as gatekeepers of crime news, reacted to the increased media interest by making available more stories that reflected and reinforced" a particular theme. "[T]he dynamics of competitive journalism created a media feeding frenzy that found news workers 'snatching at shocking numbers' and 'smothering reports of stable or decreasing use under more ominous headlines.'"<ref>{{Citation | last = Sacco | first = Vincent F. | date=May 1995 | title = Media Constructions of Crime | journal = Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science | volume = 539 | pages = 141–154}}, reprinted as chapter 2 of Potter and Kapeller (1998, pp. 37-51, esp. p. 42)</ref>
The reasons cited above for increased incarcerations (US racial demographics, Increased sentencing laws, and Drug sentencing laws) have been described as consequences of the shift in editorial policies of the mainstream media.<ref>See also {{cite book|last1=Sacco|first1=Vincent F|title=When Crime Waves|date=2005|publisher=Sage|isbn=978-0761927839}} and {{cite book|last1=Youngblood|first1=Steven|title=Peace Journalism Principles and Practices|date=2017|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-138-12467-7|pages=115–131}}</ref>
Additionally, media coverage has been proven to have a profound impact on criminal sentencing. A study conducted found that the more media attention a criminal case is given, the greater the incentive for prosecutors and judges to pursue harsher sentences. This is directly linked to the enormous increase in media coverage of crime over the past two decades. While crime decreased by 8% between 1992 and 2002, news reports on crime increased by 800% and the average prison sentence length increased by 2,000% for all crimes. Less media coverage means a greater chance of a lighter sentence or that the defendant may avoid prison time entirely.
=== Citizenship statistics === According to the Federal Bureau of Prisons, 77.6% of Federal inmates are U.S. citizens (as of April 2016). 15.2% are citizens of Mexico, and the next three countries—Colombia, Cuba, and the Dominican Republic, contribute less than 1% each. 4.9% have other or unknown citizenship. The Bureau did not state how many had come to the U.S. legally.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.bop.gov/about/statistics/statistics_inmate_citizenship.jsp | title=BOP Statistics: Inmate Citizenship | publisher=Federal Bureau of Prisons}}</ref>

{{Infobox women by region | image = Paulina Luisi.jpg | caption = [[Paulina Luisi]] was a prominent Uruguayan [[feminist]] leader, and also the first Uruguayan woman to graduate as a physician. | gii = 0.367 (2012) | gii_rank = 69th | matdeath = 29 (2010) | womparl = 16% (2014)<ref name="quotaproject.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.quotaproject.org/uid/countryview.cfm?country=232 |title=Uruguay | quotaProject: Global Database of Quotas for Women |website=QuotaProject |date= |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref> | femed = 50.6% (2010) | womlab = 68% (2014)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.TLF.ACTI.FE.ZS/countries |title=Labor force participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15-64) (modeled ILO estimate) | Data |website=Data.worldbank.org |date= |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref> | ggg = 0.6803 (2013) | ggg_rank = 77th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} '''Women in Uruguay''' are women who were born in, who live in, and are from [[Uruguay]]. According to ''Countries and Their Cultures'', there is a "very high proportion" of [[Uruguayan people|Uruguayan]] women participating in the labor force of the [[South America]]n country. The [[Constitution of Uruguay|Uruguayan legislation]] maintains that the women of Uruguay have equal rights to power, authority, and privileges". In reality, however, women are still not occupying "higher economic, [[Education in Uruguay|professional]], [[Politics of Uruguay|political]], [[Demographics of Uruguay|social]], and [[Religion in Uruguay|religious]] positions".<ref name=EC>{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/To-Z/Uruguay.html#b |title=Culture of Uruguay - history, people, clothing, traditions, women, beliefs, food, customs, family |website=Everyculture.com |date=2010-10-09 |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref> In relation to the [[Politics of Uruguay|political arena]], [[UN Women]] reported that a 2012 study made by the [[Inter-Parliamentary Union]] (IPU) ranked Uruguay as being "103rd out of 189 countries in terms of [[Women in government|representation of women]] in [[General Assembly of Uruguay|Parliament]]".<ref name=UNW>{{Cite web |url=http://www.unwomen.org/2013/01/young-uruguayan-women-aim-to-boost-their-role-in-politics/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2013-07-01 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510040406/http://www.unwomen.org/2013/01/young-uruguayan-women-aim-to-boost-their-role-in-politics/# |archive-date=2013-05-10 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Uruguay low ranking is partly due to its low political participation of women: only 16% of members of Parliament are women as of 2014. <ref name="quotaproject.org"/>
==Notable women== One prominent Uruguayan woman is [[Paulina Luisi]]. Luisi was a leader of the [[feminism|feminist movement]] in the country of [[Uruguay]]. In 1909, she became the first woman in the country to obtain a medical degree and was highly respected. She represented Uruguay in international women's conferences and traveled throughout [[Europe]]. She voiced her opinion on [[women's rights]], and in 1919, Paulina started the force for women's rights in Uruguay. By 1922, the [[Pan-American Conference of Women]] named Paulina Luisi an honorary vice president of the meeting and she continued to be an activist until Uruguay gave women the right to vote.
==Domestic violence== {{Disputed section|date=September 2017|False asseveration}} Domestic violence is a very serious problem,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/countries/americas/uruguay |title=Uruguay Human Rights | Amnesty International USA |website=Amnestyusa.org |date= |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref> especially so-called [[crimes of passion]], which continue to be tolerated under Article 36 of the Penal Code (The passion provoked by adultery) – ''Artículo 36. (La pasión provocada por el adulterio)''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.parlamento.gub.uy/Codigos/CodigoPenal/l1t2.htm# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-06-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150730062858/http://www.parlamento.gub.uy/Codigos/CodigoPenal/l1t2.htm# |archive-date=2015-07-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Since 2013, there have been ongoing political efforts to remove this provision from the Criminal Code.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.infobae.com/2013/11/26/1526432-uruguay-no-condena-el-homicidio-adulterio/ |title=Uruguay no condena el homicidio por adulterio |publisher=Infobae |date=2013-11-26 |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uypress.net/auc.aspx?46564 |title=Violencia doméstica: proponen derogar artículo 36, sobre “pasión provocada por el adulterio” - uy.press / Agencia uruguaya de noticias |website=Uypress.net |date=2013-11-26 |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.republica.com.uy/increible-pero-cierto-nuestro-codigo-exonera-homicidio-por-adulterio/407286/ |title=Nuestro Código exonera homicidio por adulterio - Diario La República |website=Republica.com.uy |date=2013-11-26 |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref> Before 2006, perpetrators of rape could avoid punishment if, after the assault, they married the victim.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = OECD Publishing | isbn = 978-92-64-07747-8 | title = Atlas of Gender and Development: How Social Norms Affect Gender Equality in non-OECD Countries | date = 2010-02-22 | page = 134}}</ref> Uruguay's law against domestic violence is ''Ley Nº 17.514'', enacted in 2002. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.parlamento.gub.uy/leyes/AccesoTextoLey.asp?Ley=17514&Anchor=# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-06-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141201141657/http://www.parlamento.gub.uy/leyes/AccesoTextoLey.asp?Ley=17514&Anchor=# |archive-date=2014-12-01 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Abortion== {{Main|Abortion in Uruguay}} The abortion law of Uruguay is very liberal compared to the other Latin American countries. In 2012, Uruguay become the second country in Latin America, after Cuba, to legalize abortion on demand (during the first 12 weeks of pregnancy).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-19986107|title=Uruguay legalises abortion|date=17 October 2012|website=Bbc.com}}</ref>
==Women in politics== Unlike most other Latin American countries, women are not very present in politics. Uruguay has one of the lowest percentage of women in politics in Latin America.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ipu.org/wmn-e/classif.htm |title=Women in Parliaments: World Classification |website=Ipu.org |date= |accessdate=2017-04-26}}</ref>
